editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A REVISION OF DOCTOR GEORGE MORLEI'S IVDGMENT IN MATTERS OF RELIGION OR AN ANSWER TO SEVERAL TREATISES WRITTEN BY HIM VPON SEVERAL OCCASIONS CONCERNING THE CHVRCH OF ROME AND MOST OF THE DOCTRINES CONTROVERTED BETWIXT HER, AND THE CHVRCH OF ENGLAND. TO WHICH IS ANNEXT A TREATISE OF PAGAN IDOLATRY BY. L. W.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: SEing my Lord of Winton is plea≈øed to wipe off that odious a≈øper≈øion of his being a Papi≈øt [which myght in the late conjuncture haue co≈øt him his civil, & endangered his natural life] by declaring not only his judgment in matters of Religion; but al≈øo the grounds, on which it relyes, contained in ≈øeverall treati≈øes, long ≈øince compounded, but never till now made publick: I pre≈øume he will not be offended, that with the re≈øpect due to his quality of Peere of the Realme, the≈øe be reviewed. Reviewed, I ≈øay, for alth√¥ Appellations lye only to hygher, Revi≈øions are committed to equal, or even inferiour courts.

He prote≈øts, he is no Papi≈øt: & I think ≈øo too. I wish it were as ea≈øy to cleere him of Calvini≈øme: of which he ownes pag. XII. that he hath beene ≈øu≈øpected, & to it he ≈øeemes enclined when he ≈øays, that God by Miracles promoted the Jdelatrous worship of the Pictures, & Relickes of Saints. This I think in reality is to make God the Authour of ≈øin: Which Bla≈øphemy I do not beleiue the Church of England will owne, th√¥ it be a choice flower in Calvin's garden.

He declares his loyalty to the government e≈øtablisht, & the Royal Family, &c. And J beleiue him in this al≈øo: nay I judge as favourably of the greate≈øt part of his rank, & moreover, that they are loyal not only for their Intere≈øt; but for con≈øcience, & out of a ≈øen≈øe of their duty to God, their ≈øoveraigne, & their country: & that he, & they, will oppo≈øe, to their Power, Schi≈øme in the Church & Faction in the State. Yet I think all their endeavours will
be ineffectual to prevent ether, con≈øidering the con≈øtitution of the Prote≈øtant Church, & qualifications of its Clergy. For as in ≈øome natural Bodyes there is a defect, which maugre all care of Phy≈øitians, cuts the thred of life, before it be ≈øpun to its ordinary length; ≈øo in ≈øome Bodyes Politick, that of the English Prote≈øtant Church, in particular. Here are ≈øome rea≈øons to proue this.

2. The fir≈øt. Protestancy is a Schi≈øme, & tho≈øe who liue in it, liue in a Schi≈øme. It is a Schi≈øme, becau≈øe it is a party ≈øeparated from the whole Catholick Church. Luther was a Schi≈ømatick, ≈øo was Calvin, ≈øo was Zuinglius, ≈øo was each Patriark of your Reformation: for each of the≈øe at their fir≈øt breaking forth, left the Whole Catholick Church, or Congregation of Christians, of what denomination ≈øoever, not any one ≈øingle Per≈øon in the whole world, to whome he (or they) did joine him≈øelf. So that if ever any man was truly Schi≈ømatick, each one of the≈øe was ≈øuch. Wherefore all who joined to them, as all Prote≈øtants did, were Schi≈ømaticks. Now it is not probable that God will giue that greate Ble≈ø≈øing of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Peace, to Schi≈ømaticks, who hate it, & oppo≈øe it.

My 2. is: Prote≈øtants are Hereticks, that is Choo≈øers of the points, which they beleiue. For the Catholick Church delivered to her children not only, what they beleiue; but al≈øo many articles which they reject. Each Prote≈øtant takes this complex, examins it, & finding ≈øome Articles not to plea≈øe him, he ca≈øts them out of his creede. Hence one rejects the Real pre≈øence, another Free will; A third Merits; a fourth the Po≈ø≈øibility of keeping God's Commandments, &c. Each one culling out what Articles he plea≈øes, & compo≈øing of them not a Catholick; but a Prote≈øtant Faith: not a Faith of the Gho≈øpels; but of this time, & their Phancyes. What more evident ≈øignes of Hereticks? Now if they be ≈øuch, can we think them fit in≈øtruments to oppo≈øe Here≈øy, who did introduce, & do ≈øtill defend it? This shall be further confirmed, by my fifth Rea≈øon.

My 3. Prote≈øtants are a Cadmean broode, they ≈øprung out of the Earth armed: & no ≈øooner did their ≈øoveraigne Lords ≈øee their faces, but they felt their Jron hands. Witne≈ø≈øe Germany, France, Hungary, Bohemia, Scotland, swethland, Denmark, the Low countryes,
& Geneva. Our English Prote≈øtants ≈øay, they are not concerned in the≈øe Rebellions: but that is not tru, for by approving, & applauding them, they make them their owne, & encourage the Practice, by commending the precedent. With what force can they teach Obedience to his Maje≈øty, who prai≈øe Rebellion again≈øt other? Or divert men from Trea≈øon, who transforme Traitors into Heroes, & canonize Regicides?

My 4. There nether is, nor ever was any Authority vnder the Heavens better grounded than that of the Catholick Clergy con≈øi≈øting of the Pope, & Bishops, was before the Reformation. It was e≈øtablisht by Chri≈øt, ≈øetled by the Apo≈øtles, ratifyed by general, & particular Councils, confirmed by an vninterrupted Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of almo≈øt fifteene hundred yeares, backt by all Laws Eccle≈øia≈øtical, & Civil, & acknowledged by all Chri≈øtians then aliue. What gentleman can ≈øay ≈øo much for his e≈øtate? What officer, for his Authority? What King, for his crowne? What Par≈øon for his Tith? What Prote≈øtant Bishop for his miter? When a Calvin, a Luther, &c. to ≈øay no more, private men, ≈øtarte vp, declame again≈øt that Clergy, as a humane invention & an Antichri≈øtian e≈øtablishment; & you applaude them, & with them trample vnder feete, the whole ≈øacred Order, & teach your followers, no ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, no obedience is due to it. When you haue taught them to breake ≈øuch cables, can you expect to bind them to their duty with ≈øingle threds?

The English Prote≈øtant pretence to Bishops doth no ≈øatisfy, 1. Becau≈øe in reality they had no canonical ordination. as we ≈øay, & proue. 2. Alth√¥ they had impo≈øition of hands, & were real Bishops [which we deny. See Anti-Haman Chapt. xxxv.] yet They entred not by the doore; but climed vp ≈øome other way, Iohn X. 1. Were not promoted according to any canonical forme ether ancient, or moderne. Wherefore what can we judge of them, but according to Chri≈øt's words, Loco citato? 3. Your fir≈øt Prote≈øtants promoted their Religion, & Spreade their noveltyes contrary to all even English Bishops, & in contempt of them, fir≈øt in Henry VIII. his time, Tindale, & others. Secondly in Q. Elizabeths time, when all the Bi≈øhops aliue dete≈øted your Reformation, & were for that ≈øtript of
their juri≈ødiction, depo≈øed from their ≈øeates, & confined. What wonder then your followers doe not regard that Cro≈øier, which you haue broken, nor honour the Miter, which they haue ≈øeene you trample vnder your feate? La≈øtly ≈øuppo≈øe your Bishops wereas validly, & canonically con≈øecrated, as any ever were, can you ≈øay, that their Authority is better grounded, than that of all the Catholick Clergy? Sure you cannot pretend to better grounds for your Authority, than our Clergy had. As it was than lawfull & laudable to three, or four private men to contradict our whole Clergy then in being, why may not ≈øome private men among≈øt you, with≈øtand yours? What rea≈øon can you alleadge again≈øt a Tub preacher? Some texts of ≈øcripture? Canons of Councils? Tradition of the Church? Laws of the Realme? All the≈øe ≈øtood in favour of our Clergy again≈øt the fir≈øt Reformers, as, & more, evidtntly than for you again≈øt your di≈ø≈øenters. So your Schi≈øme & Reformation hath deprived you of all meanes to pre≈øerue the Peace of the Church.

My 5. Is taken from the manner of your Reformation. From Rome our Ance≈øters had received by the ≈øame hands a ≈øy≈øteme of Faith, a body of Ceremonys, & ≈øome Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws. The whole Faith as nece≈ø≈øary to be beleived, the Ceremonys as decent to entertaine devotion. The laws as convenient to government, & order. And your fir≈øt Reformers changed all. Jn Faith they fir≈øt rejected the whole vnwritten word, Tradition: & a greate part of the written, ≈øcripture. They ≈øecondly perverted many places of this, by new interpretations, retaining the word without its ≈øen≈øe. The Ceremonys, & laws were treated as licentiou≈øly, throwing out of dores what≈øoever they plea≈øed. Now why may not another imitate the≈øe your Patriarks? Cur non licebit Valentiniano, quod licuit Valentino, de arbitrio ≈øuo fidem innovare? What was lawfull to Luther, is ≈øure lawfull to a Lutheran: & what was laudable in the ≈øixteenth, is not a ≈øin in the ≈øeventeenth age, to giue new interpretations to ≈øcripture, abolish other ceremonys, repeale more Canons. E≈øpecially the motiues of reforming being common. Which is

My 6. Your fir≈øt reformers rejected ≈øome Articles of Faith, as being delivered by fallible men: ≈øome Ceremonys as men's inventions,
& ≈øome laws as contrary to Evangelical liberty. Now all this holds as ≈øtrongly again≈øt what they Keepe in, as what they leaue out: for all Canons were impo≈øed by men, all Ceremonys pre≈øcribed by men, & ≈øcripture it ≈øelf brought to you, & continued among≈øt you by fallible men, as much as the real pre≈øence. Now as you blot this out of your creede, why may not another ≈øtrike out Bapti≈øme, a third the Trinity, a fourth the Incarnation, afifth the vnity of God, a ≈øixth the Deity it ≈øelf? & ≈øo farewell all Faith. What rea≈øon is there, to ≈øay, that our Roman Mi≈ø≈øioners ≈øent by S. Gregory were infallible in delivering the my≈øterys of the Trinity or Incarnation, & fallible, in ≈øpeaking of Purgatory, or the Real pre≈øence? They ≈øay they pared away the≈øe Articles, becau≈øe they were not from the beginning & were abu≈øes. But will not a Monothelit alleadge the ≈øame again≈øt the di≈øtinction of wills in Chri≈øt, an Eutychian, again≈øt the di≈øtinction of natures, a Ne≈øtorian, again≈øt the vnity of Per≈øon in him, a Macedonian, again≈øt the Divinity of the Holy gho≈øt, an Arrian, again≈øt that of the ≈øon, a Manichean, again≈øt the vnity of the Divine nature, a Iew, again≈øt the new Te≈øtament, & a Libertin, and Athei≈øt, again≈øt both old, & new, & God him≈øelf? The≈øe are not wyre drawne conclu≈øions, by ob≈øcure mediums, & far fetched illations; but natural, & obvious ≈øequels of the fundamental principles of your Reformation, which are incon≈øi≈øtent with any con≈øtancy in Faith, and ≈øettlement in Church government. So I mu≈øt conclude, that your Church building is ≈øuch, as no principles can beare; & your principles are ≈øuch, as can beare no building. By which we may gue≈ø≈øe, from whome your reformers had their vocation, from Abaddon, Apollion, the De≈øtroyer, ≈øeing their principles are good only to De≈øtroy Churchs; not at all to Build them.

In fine, a prudent man, without ca≈øting a figure, might haue ≈øeene the fate of the late troubles, in their principles, which were incon≈øi≈øtent with any ≈øetled forme of civil gouvernment & would ruin them all ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, as they did, without any hopes of re≈øt, vnle≈ø≈øe the≈øe were layd a≈øide, & the ju≈øt, & ancient government re≈øtored. The like conjecture may be made of Prote≈øtanti≈øme, its
principles being incon≈øi≈øtent with any ≈øetled forme of Faith, & Church government, will de≈øtroy them all by Schi≈øme & Here≈øyes, & no probability of a ≈øettlement vnle≈ø≈øe the≈øe be renounced, & the Ancient, Catholick, & Apo≈øtolical Faith, & Government re≈øtored. For a further proofe of this, I appeale to experience, (which is a demon≈øtration A po≈øteriori, as the former is A priori) which is

My 7. Experience shews, that tis much ea≈øier to de≈øtroy, than to ≈øettle a government ether in Church, or State. Nothing of Art, or Power was wanting to the e≈øtablishment of the Prelatical Church in England. She appeared fir≈øt with the plau≈øible colours of an Apo≈øtolical Reformation, was cherisht by Royal favour, armed the ≈øevere≈øt laws imaginable. Yet one age had not pa≈øt over her head, when the peccant humours bread within her, layd her in the du≈øt, & the crowne it ≈øelf with her, which it was hoped, she would vp hold. Both were againe re≈øtored: yet how ≈øoone was the joy of that over, & both brought againe into a like danger? Seeke no where abroade the ≈øpring of the≈øe mi≈øcheifes, they ri≈øe from the Reformation, & are in≈øeparable from the Prote≈øtant Church.

My 8. And la≈øt rea≈øon is drawne from the Prote≈øtant Clergy, it ≈øelf, which as it is modelled, & principled, can never ≈øufficiently influence the Nation to pre≈øerue its vnion in the Worship of God, & its duty to the King: to prevent Schi≈øme in the Church, & Faction in the State. This appeares by experience. The rea≈øons I re≈øerue till ≈øome further occa≈øion be given.

3. D. M. (≈øo we shall hereafter call my Lord of Winton) ≈øays in his Preface pag. 11. A french Ie≈øuit called Mainbourg publisht ≈øomething as writen by her late R. H. & he repeates afterwards four times in the Preface & once in his po≈øt ≈øcript Mainbourg the Iu≈øuit: when it was Mainbourg the ≈øecular Prei≈øt who printed it. Which that booke of his tells all the world, ≈øo did the publike Gazets, containing his di≈ømi≈ø≈øion out of the ≈øociety. His ≈øuperiors did never permit him to print it, while≈øt he was a Ie≈øuit, knowing how ≈øacred the ≈øecrets of Princes ought to be. So that paper crept about only in written copyes, ≈øeene by few, & of the≈øe not many beleiving it to be hers, who≈øe name it beares. Now D. M. hath ≈øpreade it, &
the rumor of her Change in Religion, for his owne vindication, & ≈øo prejudiced his mother the Church of England: for I doubt not but her R. H. example will moue more Powerfully to leaue that Church, than D. M. S. judgment, to retaine men in it.

He que≈øtions the Conference betwixt her R. H. & the Bishop: which being a matter of Fact, mu≈øt rely on the depo≈øition of witne≈ø≈øes, & their credit, & intere≈øt. She is po≈øitiue, he conjectural: she had no motiue, but Truth; he concerned for the honour of his Church, & his owne. His topick is, if the Bishop an≈øwered ≈øo, he was nether ≈øo Learned, nor Con≈øcientious, nor Prudent, as he ought to be. Which many will ea≈øier grant, then that her R. H. in a matter of fact would wittingly tell an vntruth.

He relates many things in his Preface to little purpo≈øe. v. c. His coming out of England with 130. l. & returning with as much, (as if he had the ble≈ø≈øing of the I≈øraelits, in the de≈øert who≈øe cloths did not weare out) his ≈øerving his Maje≈øty, & the Q. of Bohemia, without putting them to any charge, but his diet, his catechi≈øing their ≈øervants, & preaching to them, his journy to Collen, & returne to the Hague: &c. what is the publick concerned in all this? Vnle≈ø≈øe it be to helpe an Hy≈øtorian to write his life. But of heroical men even the Cradles, Rattles, & Hobby hor≈øes are venerable.

Pag. viii. He ≈øays, he did not convene with the french Hugonots, becau≈øe if They did not encourage, yet they did not, at lea≈øt had not, condemned the rebellious proceedings of their Pre≈øbiterian brethren in England again≈øt the K. & Church. Which implyes only their being idle ≈øpectators of that Tragedy, in which many think they were Actors for the wor≈øe ≈øide: & many English women in Geneva who followed their husbands thither at the end of the wars, were proofe enough. I will relate here what I find in Grotius his Di≈øcu≈ø≈øio Rivetiani Apo≈øtolici pag. 88. & 89. where having ≈øayd, that the publick Peace is di≈øturbed by that Doctrine: Licita e≈ø≈øe pro Religione ≈øubditorum in Reges arma, he adds: Hoc vir nobili≈ø≈øimus Ple≈ø≈øiacus Mornaeus, tanquam pietati con≈øentaneum, te≈øtamento etiam ≈øuo in≈øeruit. Hinc ille motus Ambaxianus, cum Reformatus Renauderius quo≈ødam ≈øui ≈øimiles in privatum conclave convoca≈ø≈øet, & dedi≈ø≈øet eis potestatem Ordinum Regni. Hinc
Beze conciones pro cla≈ø≈øico. Hinc Rupellen≈øis Conventus impudentia; qui omnes in Regno Pontificios, deinde etiam Reformatos, Regis auctoritatem ≈øequentes, declaravit ab honoribus omnibus, muneribu≈øque publicis dimovendos: praefecturas autem per omne Regnum di≈øtribuit, quibus voluit ‚Ä¢ talium con≈øiliorum auctorem ≈øibi fui≈ø≈øe PETRVM MOLINEVM te≈øtatur Theophilus Mileterius, vir nobilis, & illis, qui reformatos ≈øe dicunt, optim√® volens. Thus he. This booke hath beene printed neere the≈øe forty yeares: & never any thing alleadged again≈øt the≈øe matters of fact, that I could heare of. How will Mon≈øieur du Moulin Prebend of Canterbury reconcile with this Coun≈øil of his Father, that letter, which he printed in his fathers name?

4. The≈øe treati≈øes, having beene compo≈øed on emergent occa≈øions, without any ≈øetled de≈øigne, haue no other order than that of the time, they were compo≈øed in, among≈øt tho≈øe of the ≈øame language. J de≈øigned once to draw the matters handled in them, into ≈øome method, which would helpe to their vnder≈øtanding. But becau≈øe that would make my An≈øwer to D. M. le≈ø≈øe ≈øatisfactory (a thing mainly aimed at) I tooke the ea≈øier way, to follow my Authour, as he leades me, ≈øtep by ≈øtep, without omitting any thing material. I omit in my Revi≈øion the letters of the Regular Prei≈øt, as not grounding the judgment, in matters of Religion, of D. M. as al≈øo D. M. his letter to Trigland, as containing nothing to our purpo≈øe. For it treates only two points: the 1. of Fact, that his maje≈øty really was a Prote≈øtant. To which no an≈øwer is nece≈ø≈øary. The ≈øecond of Policy, that his Maje≈øty was to be re≈øtored to his Crowne by an Army of the ≈øtates. To this I cannot an≈øwer, as never having commenced Batchelour in Policy. Yet J will ≈øay, that God him≈øelf found a way to re≈øtore his Maje≈øty & put an end to the troubles of the State, without Armes (contrary to the expectation of D. M.) And J hope [at lea≈øt it long hath beene, is, & shall be my con≈øtant Prayer] that the God of Peace put an end to the≈øe contentious di≈øputes in the Church; that we all may come to compo≈øe but One sheepefold, vnder One sheperd. John X. 16. I thought once to omit his letter again≈øt F. Cre≈ø≈øey, as being cheifly per≈øonal: yet finding be≈øides a too ≈øevere charg on him, ≈øome Reflections vpon
his whole holy Order, I tooke leaue to review the grounds of both, yet pa≈øt it lyghtly, as entring vpon it vnwillingly.

That the Reader may with le≈ø≈øe trouble ≈øee what the Doctor ≈øays, & to what J an≈øwer, I giue his owne words, commonly at large, at lea≈øt their full ≈øen≈øe: & J marke the page, where they are to be found. This makes my Revi≈øion ≈øomewhat longer: but that is compen≈øated with the ea≈øe of di≈øcovering the Truth, which both ≈øides pretend to, but only one ≈øide contends for ≈øincerely, the other oppo≈øes with all his Power. Po≈øt ≈øcript. What is contained in my fourth Booke, pag. 111. that Factious men were pro≈øicients in the Art of promoting mi≈øcheife, was written in march la≈øt, 1683. I little dreamed to ≈øee my conjecture confirmed ≈øo ≈øoone in ≈øuch a notorious manner, as it was by The Rye Plot, & Blunderbu≈ø≈øes. div.head: THE FIRST BOOK. A REVISION OF THE CONFERENCE BETWIXT D. MORLEY AND F. DARCY, AT BRVSSELS.
THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THE fir≈øt Treati≈øe, which occurr's in this collection, is the ≈øum of a ≈øhort Conference with a Ie≈øuit at Bru≈ø≈øels. I leaue others to judg, whether it be an Historical, or a Poetical narration, or, whether it contains only ≈øincerely what was; or what might be, as not thinking it worth the while to enquire, e≈øpecially when we con≈øider, that certainly the greate≈øt part, & po≈ø≈øibly, all tho≈øe pre≈øent who could inform vs, are dead. Tho≈øe who haue been acquainted with F. Darcy, & know his great abilityes in controver≈øy, & con≈øider how weakly he is made to an≈øwer, are apt to gue≈øs, that our Authour, Poet-like brings him, & others, on the ≈øtage as he plea≈øes, & there makes him ≈øpeak, what is ea≈øie≈øt to be confuted. I rather incline to the contrary, that really there was ≈øuch a Di≈øpute & ≈øuch things, in ≈øub≈øtance alleadged pro, & con. Yet I mu≈øt beg leaue to ≈øay, that J beleme the Doctor did not ≈øubtract any ≈øtrength, from his own, nor ad any, to F. Darcy's di≈øcour≈øe; it being but ordinary that things are ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, in ≈øuch relations, as the Knight may kill the Gyant. Hence I regard little what that Father is reported to haue ≈øayd; but attend cheifly if not only, to what the Doctor alleadges again≈øt the Church, which I will defend to my power. We ≈øhall find his [D. Morley's] cheife
Argument drawn from the Communion o≈ø Infants, by which he endeauours to proue, that the Church can erre, ≈øeing it hath erred which Vicount Falkland brought again≈øt the credit of our Traditions. Which hath been already an≈øweared, th√¥ this is not taken notice of. But let vs hear the Doctor ≈øpeak.

div.p: D. Morley. The Lord Vi≈øcount Neubourg . . . & D. Morley coming to the Ie≈øuits Colledg, . . . found Father Darcy with the Lord Andover. 1. He received them very courteou≈øly, & to ≈øatisfy their curio≈øitys, . . . very frankly made vs 2. a larg narratiue of their manner of liuing, lodging, diet, together with the hours of Ri≈øing, ≈øtudying, eating, & recreations, & of all the ≈øpiritual hours, & exerci≈øes, they were bound vnto. 3. Things all of them in their ≈øeueral kinds, for the ≈øub≈øtance of them very commendable, & worthy the imitation.

Revi≈øor. I ea≈øily beleiue, that F. Darcy very wel de≈øerved this publick te≈øtimony of his kindne≈øs, 1. becau≈øe he is known to haue been very ciuil to all men. 2. Becau≈øe I am informed that it always was, & ≈øtill is the cu≈øtome of the English Ie≈øuits, to receiue courteou≈øly, & do all good offices for their country men, in all places, where they meet them: & this not only to per≈øons learned, or noble, who≈øe qualitys, or qualifications may claim it as due; but al≈øo to others on no ≈øcore di≈øtinguishable from the meane≈øt: which all tho≈øe can te≈øtify, who by de≈øign, or chance, pa≈øs by their Colledges. And their kindne≈øs to their countrymen in di≈øtre≈øs, hath not been like that of tho≈øe who Iames 2.15.16. Seing their brother, or ≈øi≈øter
naked, and destitute of dayly food, ≈øay vnto them, depart in Peace, be you warmed & filled. But they haue giuen them tho≈øe things, which are needfull to the Body. I will not mention any, who≈øe names, & nece≈ø≈øitys are ≈øcarce known, but in their neighbourhood. Was Bedlow a Pri≈øoner in Spain at Valladolid? the Ie≈øuits there labour to procure his liberty. Was Dangerfeild condemned to be hanged in the Lowcountryes? The Ie≈øuites leaue no ≈øtone vnmoued to ≈øaue his life. Was Oates in want of all things nece≈ø≈øary for food, & rayment? He finds the Ie≈øuits purse open, & hand ≈øtretcht forth to his releife: this he hath found in England, Spain, & Flanders, as long, as there was any hopes of his amendment. And alth√¥ very often this Ie≈øuitical kindne≈ø≈ø meetes with a Tru-Prote≈øtant gratitude, yet they continu ≈øtill the like good offices: ≈øo the≈øe proceed not from the compa≈ø≈øion of ≈øome tender harted Ie≈øuits; but from the ≈øpirit of their order, which they ≈øuck in with the milk of Ie≈øuiti≈øme, confirm by practice, & cheri≈øh with hopes of eternal rewards.

What Ho≈øpitals haue they not vi≈øited, where they heard any of their deare≈øt countrymen lay ≈øick? Into what Dungeons haue they not procured entrance, if an English-man were ca≈øt into them? what ≈øickne≈øs ≈øo loath≈øom, as to make the Ie≈øuits nau≈øeate the ≈øick? or ≈øo infectious, as to fright them away? what hou≈øe for infection ≈øo ≈øhut vp from commerce with all men, as to exclude the Ie≈øuits? And what danger ≈øo great, as to deter a Ie≈øuit from running into the middle of it to releiue an Engli≈øh man in di≈øtre≈øs? How many of them haue de≈øtroyed their health, how many haue lo≈øt their liues, in the≈øe works of Mercy? And how little haue the ≈øuruiuing Ie≈øuits been deterred from the like workes, by the euils befallen their Brethren, & hanging over them ≈øelues? Haue we not ≈øeen the famous fable of Pilades, & Ore≈øtes ≈øo renowned among≈øt the Pagans, out don by a Ie≈øuit, who being indicted by the name of a Benedictin, then pre≈øent, he cho≈øe rather to vndergo the ≈øentence of death, than to cleere him≈øelf by discovering the mi≈øtake, & by that, bringing the tru Benedictin into danger? The ≈øentence
was not executed; it is tru: but that doth not dimini≈øh the e≈øteem due to the Ie≈øuits heroical re≈øolution, to ≈øuffer death him≈øelf, rather than auoid it, by occa≈øioning any danger to another. He ≈øaw death, & an ignominious death according to the world, before his eyes, not to be auoided, but by a Reprieue, which he had nether meanes to ≈øollicit for, nor hopes to obtain, con≈øidering how punctually ≈øuch ≈øentences had been executed on others, not with≈øtanding all endeavours to get them ≈øu≈øpended. So his permitting the Verdict to be brought in, & the ≈øentence to pa≈øs vpon him, without making v≈øe of ≈øo certain, ≈øo obuious, ≈øo euident a meanes to trauer≈øe it, was to thru≈øt his neck into a halter, only to hinder his neighbour's danger of it. Was not this very litterally the perfecte≈øt charity, for one to giue his life for another?

2. Whence proceedes this Zeal of ≈øouls, this alacrity to encounter any danger, how great ≈øoeuer, or difficulty [except that one of offending God by ≈øin] in the≈øe pious attempts? An≈øwer: from their education, & the practice of their whole life, from their entry into the Society. At their entrance knowing how little it would avail them to gain the whole world, with the lo≈øs of their ≈øouls, & in imitation of him, who being rich, for their ≈øakes became poor, for his ≈øake they renounce all they haue, & all they hope for in this world. Their fir≈øt two yeares, or Nouiceship is ≈øpent in meditating on the life, doctrine, & death of God made Man, which aimes at nothing el≈øe, but the good of ≈øouls. And all their other exerci≈øes are to confirm them in the contempt of them≈øelues, the loue of god aboue all things, of their neighbour as them ≈øelues, & in this Zeal of ≈øouls. At their entrance into the Nouitiate, they are obliged to make for a whole month, the ≈øpiritual Exercices: in which they con≈øider fir≈øt for what end, they, & all men were created: Viz, to ≈øerue god in this world, & enioy him in the next. That all creatures what ≈øoeuer, Heauen, & Earth, Bea≈øts, Birdes, & Fi≈øhes, are de≈øigned as ≈øeruants to man, on his way to eternal bli≈ø≈ø: that euen tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øed Angels, ≈øo much our ≈øuperiours in nature, are
but our ≈øeruants, being all Heb 1.14. Ministring ≈øpirits, ≈øent forth to mini≈øter for them, who shall be heires of Saluation. That all that God & man, Chri≈øt-Ie≈øus, did, & preacht, & ≈øuffred Heb. 5.7. In the days of his flesh, was de≈øigned for that ≈øame great end, To ≈øaue ≈øouls. Now if god him≈øelf, the only competent Judg of the valu of ≈øouls, e≈øteemes them ≈øo much, how can we ≈øet too great a price vpon them? who wil regret any paines taken for their good, who hath before his eyes the trauels, the hunger, & thir≈øt, the preachings, & other labours of the Son of god? who wil be abasht at any danger in pur≈øuit of ≈øo great a good, who ≈øees with the eyes of Faith Chri≈øt crucifyed, ≈øhedding the la≈øt drop of his bloud, & ≈øuffring death, to purcha≈øe by it the life of ≈øouls? This in the Exercices.

After that monthly Recollection, & conver≈øation with only god, & his ble≈ø≈øed Saints, their whole employments are ≈øuch, as may prepare them for that great work, the greate≈øt of all divine workes, as S. Denis ≈øays, To cooperate with God in the Conver≈øion of ≈øouls. Do they pray? It is to vnite them≈øelues the clo≈øer to Almighty God, that ≈øo they may be fitter in≈øtruments for him to work with, & encrea≈øe the Zeal of ≈øouls. Do they ≈øtudy? It is to render them≈øelues more capable to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them. Do they Teach Do they Preach? It is to direct men to Heauen by declaring to them ≈øauing Truths. Their recreations, eating, drinking, ≈øleeping aim at the ≈øame end; for by them they con≈øerue, or repayr their ≈øtrength, that they may continu to ≈øerue god, & their neighbour. Thus all the actions of each day, month, year, & their whole life are employed in procuring the ≈øalvation of them≈øelues, & their neighbour.

They ri≈øe at Four in the morning, with their harts full of gratitude to god, who hath pre≈øerued them that night; & petitions for a ble≈ø≈øing on their Actions that day. At four and a halfe they begin their meditation, or mental Prayer which la≈øts for a whole hour, on ≈øome pa≈ø≈øage of the life, or point of doctrine of Chri≈øt. Then they ≈øay or hear Ma≈ø≈øe: which being a Commemoratiue Sacrifice of that, on the cro≈øs, renews the memory of what god did, & ≈øuffred
to ≈øaue ≈øouls: & con≈øequenly renews Zeal to procure it. The re≈øt of the morning is ≈øpent either in mental, or vocal Prayer, or ≈øtudy, or dealing with their neighbor, according to the order of Superiors, or pre≈øent occa≈øions. Only one quarter before dinner is a≈ø≈øigned for a ≈øeuere review of their Actions, of the whole morning, & taking a ≈øtrict Account of them all, in the pre≈øence of god. For what they find well don, they giue thanks to god, the Authour of all good: for what is reprehen≈øible, they ask God pardon, & endeauour to di≈øpo≈øe them≈øelues to receiue it, by a true ≈øorrow for hauing offended him, & a ≈øtrong re≈øolution neuer more to offend him. Dinner is followed with a Recreation (as they call it) for an hour, which is ≈øpent in di≈øcour≈øes of pious things, or others indifferent. The re≈øt of the afternoon till ≈øupper is ≈øpent as the morning [except Ma≈ø≈øe, & the fir≈øt hour of Prayer.] After ≈øupper one hour is allowed for mutual conver≈øation: then the great Litanyes of all Saints are ≈øayd by all together, which la≈øt about a quarter: a ≈øecond quarter is a≈ø≈øigned to prepare the morning's meditation: a third for the Examen of their con≈øcience, & the la≈øt to go to bed: which all mu≈øt do by nine. This is their ordinary di≈øtribution of time, for the whole day. Which I hear was exactly ob≈øerved by the Ie≈øuits during their clo≈øe impri≈øonment, to the a≈øtonishment of their keepers, who could not tell how they could ≈øo regularly do all tho≈øe ≈øeveral pious Actions at the ≈øame hours, hauing no communication with one an other: they did not, they could not know, that this was the di≈øtribution of time v≈øed in their Colleges.

I need not ≈øay, that each one hath a chamber to him≈øelf which ≈øerues as much for mode≈øty as conuenience: that this is fitted [as that of Elizeus, or Elisha 4 Reg. c. 10 by the Sunamite] with things nece≈ø≈øary for v≈øe; without ≈øuperfluitys: that their diet is frugal, without daintys: & their whole way of liuing is decent, & neate; without ether vanity, which they abhor; or ≈øordidne≈ø≈øe, in the Pouerty, which they profe≈øs. In one thing they think they cannot be too prodigal; in their churches, their Altars, their ≈øacred Ve≈ø≈øels,
& ve≈øtments. They know God to be the King of Kings, & Lord of Lords: & adoring him aboue all the world they think it all too little for him. Wherefore what≈øoeuer they can procure by them≈øelues, or by their freinds, they employ freely in the Diuine ≈øeruice. From the ≈øplendour of their churches, ≈øome ≈øtrangers to their manner of liuing, gue≈øs them to be exceeding rich whereas did they know all, they would correct that errour. At Bruges they haue a noble church; & but a pittifull building for their own aboad. They are though't to flourish as much in France, as in any part of Europe: yet a ≈øtrict ≈øuruey being made of all their reuenues vnder the French dominions by order of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, they were found not to haue two hundred French Liuers per annum, In ≈øingula Capita. Whereas ≈øome other very au≈øtere & reformed Religious Orders, & who are not noted as rich, haue according to the ≈øame ≈øurueyours aboue 1300. liuers, In ≈øingula Capita. Hence is euident, that di≈øcour≈øe of Ie≈øuits riches is an effect of malice in ≈øome, & of ignorance in mo≈øt men.

This J ≈øay to ≈øupply that part of the Conference, which you only hint at, by the words aboue cited, that He, that Father, Made a larg narratiue of their manner of liuing, &c. This Narratiue, had you giuen it to the publick, would haue giuen greater ≈øatisfaction, than mine, becau≈øe the Father had greater experience, than J haue. Howeuer J do not fear to be blamed in the whole, or any part of this relation, ≈øo great a confidence J haue in tho≈øe Informations J rely on.

3. Hence I am not much ≈øurpri≈øed, to ≈øee you approue the≈øe Actions, as Very commendable, and worthy the Imitation for the ≈øub≈øtance of them. A per≈øon of ≈øo quick a wit, & ≈øo ≈øolid iudgment, could not haue any other opinion of them. Yet J dare you to ≈øquare the≈øe circles, or reconcile the≈øe contradictions: the Actions of Ie≈øuits are for the ≈øub≈øtance of them commendable. And: the Cheife action of Je≈øuits is not commendable, viz, the Ma≈ø≈øe, which you, & your Brethren hold to be downright Idolatry. Now Ma≈ø≈øe is not only one
of the Ie≈øuits religious Actions; but it is the very Cheife of them all. For as in the old law all its rites, ceremonys & ≈øacrifices were but figures, or types of the Sacrifice of the Cro≈øs which was de≈øigned from the beginning, & which being intentionally pre≈øent in God's vnder≈øtanding did moue his goodne≈øs euer ≈øince Adam's fall to pardon men's ≈øins & grant them tho≈øe Ble≈ø≈øings, to which, in vertue of that Sacrifice they had a right, on which account the true Lamb of God is ≈øayd to be Occi≈øus ob origine mundi Apoc. 13.8. Sacrificed from the beginning of the world, ≈øo in the new all our deuotions, all our prayers, all our pennances, our interiour, & exteriour vertuous Actions, regard the ≈øame ≈øacrifice of the Cro≈øs, & that of the Ma≈ø≈øe, which is a commemoration, or repetition of that other of the Cro≈øs. So all our deuotions are only as preparations to it, or Thanks giuings for it, & the graces we receiue by it. Thus in the natural Body all Actions vegetatiue & ≈øen≈øitiue proceed from the head, & hart, & are cheifly de≈øigned to nourish, helpe, & defend them: & in the my≈øtical Body, of Religious Actions, & Dutys they all proceed from, & end in the Bloudy Sacrifice of the Cro≈øs, & in the vnbloudy ≈øacrifice of the Ma≈øs, for as much as in them is contained our ble≈ø≈øed ≈øaviour CHRIST-IESVS God ble≈ø≈øed for euer more, the Œë, & Œü, Beginning & end of our Religion, in whom all our Devotions concenter, he being the Founder, & Authour of our Faith, the Ground, & Anker of our Hope, & the Principle & Object of our Charity. Which three vertues are Cheifly, or rather ≈øolely aimed at in Religion. Haec maxim√®, imo vero ≈øola in Religione ≈øequenda ≈øunt. Aug. Enchir. c. 4.

Now if Mo≈øs the cheife≈øt, & noble≈øt of Religions Actions be Idolatry, as you ≈øay el≈øewhere, how do you ≈øay now it is Lawfull, nay Commendable, & Worthy the imitation? If it be ≈øo, certainly it is not Idolatry. But Contradictions are vnavoidable, when we combate a known truth, which by ≈øurpri≈øal will force an acknowledment of it ≈øelf, altho we arm our ≈øelues again≈øt it when adverti≈øed. Hence you approue here the ≈øame thing in Gro≈øs, which you condemn
in retail. I leaue you this bone to pick, & proceed.

div.p: D. Morley. 1. My lord Andover wisht, that ≈øome learned, & moderate men of the Churchs of Rome, & England might meet & debate freely, & charitably the Differences between the two Churchs, which are not ≈øo many, nor ≈øo great, but they might find out ≈øome expedient to compo≈øe them. 2. D Morley Sayd it would be imprudent, & vn≈øafe for him to di≈øoute of Religion in Bru≈ø≈øels: th√¥ the Preists in England had often with all boldne≈ø≈øe, freedome, & ≈øafety, before many witne≈ø≈øes mantained their opinions. So vpon my life may you do here, ≈øayd F. Darcy, & be ≈øo far from offending me, as J shall take it as a favour.

1. Revi≈øor. Altho I readily grant the capacity of that noble man to be great; yet I mu≈øt beg leaue to dout, whether he were a competent Judg of the mo≈øt ready way to end the Differences in points of Faith betwixt di≈ø≈øenting Churchs: this requiring a greater ≈øearch into points of Doctrine, & intere≈øt, then Per≈øons of his quality, & education are willing commonly to vndergo. Truth is ever pretended on both ≈øides; but it is onely pretended on the one ≈øide, which in reality applyes all its indu≈øtry to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, for ether motives of Pa≈ø≈øion, Intere≈øt, Envy, Spite, Reveng, & what el≈øe is contrary to the law of God. When the≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the hart, the head is bu≈øyed to make Vertu pa≈øs for vice, & vice for vertu,
to adorn Falshood with the dre≈øs of Truth, & by ≈øophi≈øtical rea≈øons make Truth be ≈øu≈øpected of Falshood. He will by calumayes as black as Hell, reader odjoas, or contemptible the per≈øons, who oppo≈øe his Pa≈ø≈øion, & thwart his Jntere≈øt, Cro≈øs his de≈øign, & procure his real good, by di≈øcovering his errours, & by that inviting him to return to the ancient Faith, & Communion of the Church, which he broke through want of Charity. It is hard to di≈øcover the wiles of tho≈øe Foxes, & ways of the≈øe wolves, the fraudulent, or fierce enemys of the Churchs Peace; to ≈øee through that mi≈øt which they rai≈øe on purpo≈øe not to be ≈øeen, & to fathom the≈øe Depths of Sathan. Apoc. 2.24. Now th√≤ this noble man's capacity was great, yet perchance not ≈øufficient for ≈øo ob≈øcure, & intricate a work.

Yet when all the doubling of the≈øe Foxes are di≈øcovered, & the ≈øecrets of their harts layd open, yet the work is not half don. The greate≈øt difficulty remaines, to wean them from tho≈øe beloved wandrings: it being one of the di≈ømalle≈øt effects of the≈øe ≈øinfull errours, that by ≈øecret, yet power full charmes, they fix the will in the loue of them. Hence S. Pro≈øper. Tantum nocet error
div.l: Vt juuet errare, & veteris contagia morbi
Tam blande obrepunt, vt quo languetur ametur.

l.hi: Such charmes before our eyes doth errour lay,
That it e'en makes vs loue to go a≈øtray:
Whil≈øt th' evil ≈øpreads, we vnconcerned go,

div.p:
The ≈øecretary of nature Aristotle never div'd deeper into the hart of man, then when he ≈øayd, that alth√¥ Rea≈øon ≈øeemes to hold the ≈øcales, & di≈øcern betwixt two contending parts, yet in reality it is the hart, the will, which deliberates, & decides the thing in que≈øtion. Hence comes that variety of judgments on the ≈øame individual Action, of which one shall make a Panegyrick, another a Satyre. And th√¥ the lyght of Truth, & the appearance of God, be ≈øo cleer, as not to be concealed, yet this shall be as ineffectual,
as to all influence on our Actions, as if they were dreames, a ≈øen≈øual man prefers Plea≈øure before his Honour; A vertuous man the contrary. So we judg [as we are affected] not as we should: our will doth not follow, but lead nay drag after it our Rea≈øon, & that with ≈øo ≈øweet a violence, that it is not perceived without much labour, great attention, & ≈øtrict ≈øearch into the beginning, progre≈ø≈øe, & end of our Actions. This is the root of all incoherent di≈øcour≈øes, & illogical deductions of Pa≈ø≈øion, & intere≈øt or ≈øelf-loue, which in many prevail over Truth, controul the inclinations to good, & make men break all their dutys to God & their country, to Prince, frends, & Relations: & th√¥ they ≈øee what is better, yet do the contrary. 3. Wherefore it is both an V≈øual ≈øaying, & a Setled judgment of Catholicks, that Prote≈øtants remaining ≈øuch, cannot be ≈øaved. Becau≈øe that name imports two greivous ≈øins: Schi≈øme, by ≈øeparation from

Wherefore F. Darcy's argument remaines in force, that it is ≈øafer to joine with the Catholicks, than with the Prote≈øtants (as it was ≈øafer to avoyd Trea≈øon, to joine with the king, than with the Parliament) there being no ≈øin in remaining in the Communion of the Catholick Church: & two great ≈øins, Schi≈øm, & Here≈øy, in joining with the Prote≈øtants.

You ≈øay, that this Rea≈øon would proue, that in S. Au≈øtin's time it was ≈øafer to joine with the Donati≈øts, than with the Catholicks, ≈øeing both ≈øides agreed that the Donati≈øts could be ≈øaved; & the Donati≈øts denyed that po≈ø≈øibility to the Catholicks. An≈øwer: you are here gro≈ø≈øely mi≈øtaken [pardon that word] for S. Austin never ≈øayd a Donati≈øt remaining ≈øuch Could be ≈øaved; nay a great part of his workes again≈øt them is employed to proue, that they cannot be ≈øaved, that their Bapti≈øm avayles them nothing, but ≈øerues for their greater damnation. Let me be≈øeech you, only to open any leafe, any page, of the ≈øeveral bookes written again≈øt them, there is none, which will not correct that mi≈øtake. What you should ≈øay is, only, that both ≈øides owned tru Bapti≈øm among≈øt the Donati≈øts; which the≈øe denyed among≈øt Catholicks. Which argument the Donati≈øts
not only myght; but did make v≈øe of, to pervert Catholicks, as you may ≈øee in S. Au≈øtin L. 1. de Bapt. cont. Donat. c. 3. & l. 2. cont. Petilianum, c. 108. & el≈øe where.

To this I an≈øwer, that ≈øuch a rea≈øon from a Donati≈øt to a Catholick is of no force, he having no good ground at all for that rea≈øon to rely on, & therefore denying Bapti≈øme in the Catholick Church, only out of a peevishne≈ø≈øe of nature, & Religion: & it was by them ≈øayd with no more cau≈øe, than Quakers had to ≈øay: Thou art damned, when they had nothing el≈øe to ≈øay. Where as Catholicks proue that A≈ø≈øertion of theirs with jrrefragable rea≈øon, drawn from tho≈øe two crying ≈øins, Schi≈øme, & Here≈øy, of which we accu≈øe the Prote≈øtants, & the≈øe do not, nay cannot ≈øufficiently cleere. That tho≈øe of the Donatists were frivolous, is evident, for they ≈øayd: ≈øome Bishops of the Catholick Communion were Traditores, had delivered the ≈øacred bookes to the Per≈øecutors, & that all Catholicks by communicating with them, did contract the ≈øame guilt, & had lo≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt. To which the Catholicks an≈øwered, 1. that tho≈øe Bishops accu≈øed of that shamefull compliance with the jmperial Edicts again≈øt Chri≈øtians, were jnnocent of that crime, which was never ≈øufficiently proved vpon them: & no man ought to be condemned vnle≈ø≈øe the crime be evidently proved again≈øt him.

2. They an≈øwered, that alth√¥ the per≈øons accu≈øed were really guilty, yet their per≈øonal guilt could not prejudice all Catholicks communicating with them: becau≈øe another man's ≈øin cannot prejudice me, vnle≈ø≈øe J make it my own by commanding, or per≈øwading, approving, defending, or imitating it. Now the Catholicks were ≈øo far from being acce≈ø≈øory to that pretended ≈øin in another, that they dete≈øted the ≈øin, & always condemned it, in all per≈øons, who were really guilty of it: but never could find ≈øufficient grounds to pronounce tho≈øe accu≈øed by the Donati≈øts guilty of it, as tho≈øe would haue them doe.

They an≈øwered 3. that ≈øuppo≈øing (not granting) that the Per≈øons accu≈øed were really guilty, & that guilt had infected the whole body of Catholicks, by communicating with them: yet their Bapti≈øm myght be valid, this not depending on the Per≈øonal ≈øanctity of its Mini≈øter, but on the ju≈øtitution, & promi≈øes of Chri≈øt, & the operation of the Holy Gho≈øt. Au≈øtin ≈øayd he did not regard Peter when he Baptizes, nor Paul, nor Iohn, nor Iudas; but he con≈øidered the Holy Gho≈øt, who is the Bapti≈øt, who ever he be who washes the body, & pronounces the words, as Mini≈øter of that Sacrament.

You ≈øe how frivolous the rea≈øons of the Donati≈øts were, to deny the validity of Bapti≈øm in the Catholick Church. It ≈øeemes not di≈øcreet in an English Prote≈øtant to mention the Donati≈øts, there being ≈øo great a re≈øemblance betwixt the≈øe two ≈øchi≈ømatical Churchs, that they may ≈øeem ≈øi≈øters, & the later to haue copyed the other: which appeares by the≈øe paralel points.
1. Donati≈øts were no where out of one corner of the world, Africa: & Prote≈øtants of the Church of Eng. [that is ≈øuch as agree with her in points of Doctrine, & Hierarchy] no where out of England.

3. Tho≈øe endeavoured to ju≈øtify their ≈øeparation with ≈øome pretended faults of particular men: you to ju≈øtify yours alleadg ≈øome indi≈øcreet devotions of old women, and vnwary words of ≈øome (otherwi≈øe) pious Authours.

4. Tho≈øe appealed to ≈øome parts of ≈øcripture, which you v≈øe again≈øt vs; And the Fathers proved again≈øt them the Vniver≈øality of the Church, & the nece≈ø≈øity of Communion with her, out of the ≈øame texts, which we v≈øe again≈øt you.
5. Donati≈øts called Rome the ≈øeat, or Chair of pe≈øtilence; you call it a Pe≈øt-hou≈øe, [letter to her R. H. P. 17.] & the ≈øeat of Antichri≈øt.

6. Tho≈øe had their Circumcellions, who thought to do God good ≈øervice, in murthering Catholicks: you haue ≈øome of the ≈øame per≈øwa≈øion, as appeares by their workes. 7. Tho≈øe had the Maximiani≈øts, who left them for the ≈øame rea≈øons, they had broken off Communion with the Church, the≈øe haue the Presbiterians, & others, who will not conforme with them vpon the ≈øame grounds, for which they refu≈øe to conform to the Catholick Church.

8. And la≈øtly: the Non-conformist donatists made evident to the world, that the Donati≈øts had no real ground to break the Catholick Communion, by forcing them to ≈øolue their owne Objections again≈øt the Church, [of which S. Au≈øtin l. 2. Retract. C. 35.] And your Non conformi≈øts with the ≈øame ≈øucce≈ø≈øe force you to an≈øwer all your pretences again≈øt vs, & breake tho≈øe weapons, with which you haue hitherto fought again≈øt the Church.

Tho≈øe who will take the paines to examin further the Donati≈øts principles, will di≈øcover more points of agreement betwixt them, & you. I am now arrived at the end of this real, or pretended Conference, without omitting any one material point of it. div.head: THE SECOND BOOK. A REVISION OF THE ARGVMENT FROM SENSES AGAINST TRANSVBSTANTIATION.
THE PREFACE.
div.p:
I Never began to read any Treati≈øe with greater Horrour, nor ended, with greater Indignation, than this, which J now come to review. Horrour, to ≈øee doubts of divine Doctrine ≈øubmitted to the depo≈øitions of facultys common to Bea≈øts, a jury of the Sen≈øes impanelled to decide controver≈øys of Faith, & ≈øet on a throne, to judge the judg of the world, & determine the meaning of the words of eternal Truth, of divine veracity, alth√¥ they are vncapable of vnder≈øtanding the words of the meane≈øt vnder≈øtanding, & mo≈øt illiterate Pe≈øant. I expect shortly to ≈øee ≈øome other appeal to Bea≈øts ≈øeing many of
the better ≈øort of the≈øe ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe man, as to quickne≈ø≈øe of Sen≈øes, which in them are much more perfect, then in mo≈øt, if not al men: & therefore may be ≈øayd to be more competent judges of the objects of Sen≈øes, then men can be. Indeed Seducers proficiunt in peius, wax wor≈øe, & wor≈øe, 2. Tim. 2.13. & it is not ≈øo great a ≈øtep from the Sen≈øes of men, to tho≈øe of Bea≈øts, (which are of the ≈øame Species, & are rather more, than le≈ø≈øe perfect in their kind J as it is from the Church directed by the Holy Gho≈øt, for our jn≈øtruction in Faith, to Carnal ≈øen≈øes: That having ≈øomething of divine, by rea≈øon of the Holy Gho≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øting; the≈øe being meere Corporal, & below all that hath any thing of Rea≈øon. A fit judge indeed for ≈øuch a Church, as the Prote≈øtant is!

My horrour changed into Indignation, when I heard the Verdict brought in by this Iury, the Sentence pronounced by this Vmpire, this Brutish judge [yet from ≈øuch a Iudg little le≈ø≈øe could be hoped for, in ≈øuch a matter] by which, the Scripture is ≈øilenced, Tradition trampled vnder foot, Fathers rejected, the Practice & Faith of the whole Catholick Church condemned, the Communion with all Faith full, all the Catholick Church renounced, & a horrid & execrable Schi≈øme authorized, And all this vpon the depo≈øition of ≈øo vile a witne≈ø≈øe, & by the Sentence of ≈øo contemptible a judg, as Carnal ≈øen≈øe. And this Sentence accepted of, recommended by a learned Doctor of divinity, & a pretended Ryght Reverend Bishop. Is Christianity, is Divine Faith brought to this?

Yet J find one ≈øign of Mode≈øty (vnle≈ø≈øe it were rather Cunning, & craftine≈ø≈øe in adorning the ≈øtage for this piece of Pageantry, & di≈øpo≈øing for this extravagant judgment) that there is ether no mention at all, of the grounds of Catholick Faith in this treati≈øe: or el≈øe it is ≈øo ≈øilent, & low a mention, that it is ≈øcarce perceptible. For had you ≈øet before the eyes of your Readers, the practice of the Church, the Te≈øtimonys of Fathers, the decrees of councils, the written, & vnwritten word of God, in fine the vnanimous vote of the primitiue & pre≈øent Church, averring that to be Chri≈øts Body
& Bloud, the Readers would not haue heard the ≈øentence of this mock judg, would haue pulled him off the Bench, & forced him to yeild the victory to Truth. For if we Mu≈øt pull out our eye if it ≈øcandalize vs: we mu≈øt shut our eyes, ≈øtop our cares, renounce all our Sen≈øes, when thy contradict God's expre≈ø≈øe word. But if by this you made ≈øure of ≈øuch a ≈øentence, as you wisht, you di≈øcovered the vnju≈øtice of it, by not admitting the plea of the contrary party. For, qui ≈øtatuit aliquid parte inaudit√¢ alter√¢, aequum licet ≈øtatuerit, hand aequus fuit.

This argument is not of the Doctors invention, it is as old, as the Sacramentarian Here≈øy. Berengarius v≈øed it, ≈øo did Zuinglius, & Calvin, & F. Stillingfleet, & G. Burnet. And the an≈øwer is as common. To confute this Treati≈øe it were enough to reprint the 33. Chapter of Anti-Haman: ≈øo no new reply is nece≈ø≈øary. Yet lea≈øt he think him≈øelf neglected, I will review what he ≈øays.

div.p:
SEn≈øes no competent judges in this Controver≈øy. Are not our Sen≈øes the ≈øame now, as they were a thou≈øand or ≈øixteen hundred yeares ago? Are their objects changed? And had not men then as much rea≈øon to rely on their Sen≈øes, in framing a judgment of their objects, as now? Sure they had. Now what judgments did Ancients frame of this object, in debate? Let S. Cyril of Hieru≈øalem ≈øpeak for all the re≈øt.
Alth√¥ it ≈øeemes to be Bread, yet it is not Bread: Alth√¥ it ≈øeemes to be wine, yet it is not wine. Thus this great ≈øaint, & ancient Father, delivering Chri≈øtian Doctrine in a Catechi≈øme. No le≈ø≈øe; but rather more evident are the words of the ≈øame Apo≈øtle, 2. Cor. 10.4. The weapons of our warfare, ≈øays he, are not carnal; but myghty through God, to the pulling down of strong holds; casting down imaginations, & every hygh thing, that exalteth it ≈øelfe

2. He rejects inward Sen≈øes: Casting down all jmaginations.
3. He teaches that our vnder≈øtanding mu≈øt al≈øo be ≈øubject. Bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Chri≈øt.

Thus according to the Apo≈øtle, all facultys of ≈øoul & body, ≈øpiritual, & carnal, interiour, & exteriour, mu≈øt vayle bonnet to Faith, which is termed Myghty through God. 3. If we con≈øult Rea≈øon in this debate, we shall ≈øee, that Sen≈øes ought not to be admitted as judges, it being ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible, they should vnder≈øtand the matter in que≈øtion: & therefore cannot po≈ø≈øibly pronounce ≈øentence, on ether ≈øide. What is the meaning of tho≈øe words: of our Ble≈ø≈øed ≈øaviour: This is my Body: this is my Bloud: for I ≈øuppo≈øe your jmpiety is not arrived to that heygth, as to deny his words to be tru: or ≈øay, you would not beleiue any thing to be, what he plainly, & vndeniably ≈øays it is. q.p: Sen≈øes cannot judg of things, which are not their proper objects: But ≈øuch are the things in debate in this controver≈øy: Therefore ≈øen≈øes cannot judg of the≈øe things.

div.p:
The≈øe Premi≈ø≈øes are ≈øo evidently tru, that J think it enough
only to proue the fir≈øt Propo≈øition: & this I doe by induction, for nether eye, nor no≈øe, nor palate, nor hand, nor eare can ≈øee, ta≈øt ≈ømel, feale, or heare the ≈øignification of words, wherefore no ≈øen≈øe can perceiue it. The only doubt can be about Hearing, by rea≈øon of the convexion betwixt the ≈øound of an Articulate word (which is the object of the eare) & the ≈øignification of it: yet even here my Propo≈øition is tru: for the ≈øame articulate ≈øound is in≈øignificant to one who vnder≈øtands it not: & ≈øometimes ≈øignifyes different things to per≈øons of different langages. v. c. Lego, to a Latini≈øt ≈øignifyes I reade: to a Grecian, I ≈øpeake: to an English man nothing. Yet the ≈øound in the eare is the ≈øame to all the≈øe three. Jndeed if it were not ≈øo, by learning anew language, our eares should be changed, & framed in a different manner, to repre≈øent the new ≈øignification. Which I ≈øuppo≈øe no body will ≈øay.

As to the other Propo≈øition [the minor] that our di≈øpute is about the ≈øignification of tho≈øe words, is as evident: For our ≈øentiment is grounded on the words being taken litterally: yours vpon their being taken figuratively. Both which are the ≈øeverall ≈øignifications.

One thing only occurres in an≈øwer to this, viz, that the litteral ≈øignification is ≈øo ab≈øurd, that it cannot be admitted. An≈øwer: this is ≈øayd, but not proved: & in du place the≈øe ab≈øurditys will be confidered, & J hope found to be no b≈øurditys. An≈øwer 2. this doth not ≈øatisfy my rea≈øon: for no Ab≈øurdity can make any faculty judg of what it cannot know. As no Ab≈øurdity can make me a competent judg of a compo≈øition in the Chine≈øe language, of which J am entirely ignorant.

Here I myght lay down my pen, it already appearing, that all you can alleadg from Sen≈øes can ≈øignify nothing, ≈øeing they cannot depo≈øe of a thing they are totally ≈øtrangers to: & you ≈øay nothing but from Sen≈øes. Jt was indeed a great ≈øigne of a bad cau≈øe, when you appealed from the proper judges, to tho≈øe, who are in competent: & there plead as earne≈øtly, as if you were in earne≈øt, when
all is only to amu≈øe your reader, by drawing his Attention, from what myght in≈øtruct him, to what cannot, as women amu≈øe children with Rattles. Indeed your di≈øcour≈øe, & the≈øe, are alike ≈øignificant, as will appeare, by di≈øcu≈ø≈øing the particulars. I will before I pa≈ø≈øe to that, enquire further into the nature, & force of ≈øen≈øes.

div.p: 1. THat by our Sen≈øes we come to the knowledg of ≈øeveral objects, is an vndoubted Truth. Our vnder≈øtanding by its Creation receives little or no knowledg at all, if we beleiue Phylo≈øophers: & therefore Aristotle compares it to a white Paper, or a cleere cloth to paint on, in which there is nether one letter written, nor one line drawne: the taske of filling vp that Paper, or table, being left to objects, which by the meanes of Sen≈øes, as by their Pens, or Pen≈øils, write or delineat their Re≈øemblances, or Pictures, [which are the knowledges, we haue of them] in our mind.

Some think this is as the mo≈øt noble, ≈øo the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary work of ≈øen≈øes, & that which nature, in giving them to vs cheifely, & even onely intended. Others ≈øay this is onely an accidental, & additional employment ≈øcarce intended directly by nature: which in the fir≈øt place de≈øigned them as ≈øo many life-guards, or ≈øentinells, to man, to di≈øcover, & giue timely notice of Approching objects, & their condition of Freinds, or Foes, good, or bad, hartfull,
& di≈øplea≈øant; or plea≈øant, & confortable: to the end man myght not be ≈øurpri≈øed; but prepared to receiue tho≈øe favourable, & reject & defend it ≈øelfe from the re≈øt. This is the opinion of the french Authour of The ≈øearch of Truth, in the fir≈øt book of that work: in which by many in≈øtances, & experiences he proues that the Sen≈øes are frequently mi≈øtaken, & deceiue vs, when ≈øoever they ≈øtretch beyond that duty, of informing man of the advantage, or disadvantage he may receiue from an vnexpected, & otherwi≈øe vnknowne neyghbour: yet it is vndeniable, that they are ≈øub≈øervient, & very officious in providing matter for the vnder≈øtanding to worke vpon, & the ≈øyght aboue all the re≈øt. Tho≈øe who are de≈øirous of larger proo≈øes of the deceipts of tho≈øe ≈øentinels, & of the fal≈øe allarmes they giue, may find ≈øatisfaction in that neate Authour. My de≈øigne being here no other, than to shew, that the Sen≈øes cannot be always relyed on, in the reports they make, it will be ≈øufficient to proue by ≈øome few, but cleere, & vndeniable examples, that the Sen≈øes ≈øome, nay many times do mi≈øinforme vs, by repre≈øenting things otherwi≈øe than they are; and (which is cheifely to our purpo≈øe) ≈øome times things, which are not.

Fir≈øt as to Feeling, or Touching, Tactus, tho≈øe who haue lo≈øt aleg, or an Arme, feele many times the ≈øame paine, as it were in the hand, or foote, as if they had them. Mr. Starkey having in the Kings ≈øervice lo≈øt aleg, felt a paine as in that foote [th√¥ it had beene long before buryed] as if it were tickled in the ≈øole with a Feather, ≈øometimes as if it had beene trodden on: with a paine ≈øometimes dull, ≈øometimes quick, & sharpe, not only equal, to; but even ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing tho≈øe, which he had felt, before that lo≈ø≈øe. It is not to my purpo≈øe to enquire into, & explicate the cau≈øes of the≈øe effects, my de≈øigne not being to write of meere Phylo≈øophical things, further then is nece≈ø≈øary to di≈øcover that the Sen≈øes, of Feeling doth deceiue vs, by repre≈øenting a ≈øub≈øtance, where there is none: & ≈øuch is that ≈øen≈øation of a Feather tickling, and a foote, or ≈øome other hard body pre≈ø≈øing vpon ours, alth√¥ this it ≈øelf is no more in being.

Our Ta≈øt doth in alike manner deceiue vs, for Tobacco being totally con≈øumed in a Pipe, the Ayre ≈øucked thorough it shall for a while haue the perfect ta≈øt of the ≈ømoke of Tobacco alth√¥ it be pure Ayre, with a tincture of the con≈øumed weede from the warmed Pipe. Alike in≈øtance we haue in ≈øome cider (which S. Au≈øtin calls Vinum vino≈øi≈ø≈øimum de pomis) and Metheglin, or Hydromel, which if good, & ≈øtale, & well kept, hath ≈øo ≈øtrong a ta≈øt of Aqua vitae, that ≈øome could ≈øcarce be per≈øwaded, that one halfe of it, was not of that di≈øtilled liquour.

The Smell is the dulle≈øt, & ea≈øy e≈øt impo≈øed vpon of all Sen≈øes. Hold a clod of bay falt, newly taken vp about Bro√ºage in France [where there is always great quantity of it] to the no≈øe of a man hoodwinkt, & he shall take it for a no≈øegay of violets.

3. The quicke≈øt, & lea≈øt corporal of all our Sen≈øes is the ≈øyght: yet it is obnoxious to many deceipts. The appearances of a medal in aba≈øin, full of water, which th√¥ at the bottone ≈øeemes at the top: jtem of an oare, which halfe vnder water ≈øeemes broken, I omit, as trivial, & ordinary. Our ≈øyght discouers no di≈øtance betwixt the top of a hill, or the ridge of a hou≈øe beyond which the moone ri≈øes: nay our eyes repre≈øent her as touching, or contiguous to them. It repre≈øents the ≈øun, & moone as plaine, alth√¥ both be ≈øpherical. It repre≈øents the d√Øameter of the moone (& ≈øun) le≈ø≈øer when shee is in our meridian, then when she is r√Ø≈øing aboue, or falling vnder our Hori≈øon: th√¥ it should appeare greater as being a whole ≈øemidiameter of the Earth, neerer vs, when in our meridian, then when in the ea≈øt or we≈øt, if she moues in a perfect circle. Our eyes repre≈øent the ≈øun, & moone, as at an equal di≈øtance: & all the fixt ≈øtarres, as in one planis ≈øphere: which our new Scepticks will ≈øcarce a≈ø≈øent to.

Our eyes in ≈øublunary things are as vncertaine. Looke from a Bridge ≈øteedfa≈øtly on the water, & this shall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand, & the other moue. Inaship vnder ≈øayl, the shore ≈øeemes to moue; & not the ship: Hence the Poet: Terraeque Vrbe≈øque recedunt.

The land, & Townes do run away

Looke in a ≈øtreyght line with a Canon bullet, not with≈øtanding the the vnconceivable ≈øwiftne≈ø≈øe of its motion, it will ≈øeeme to the eye to haue none at all, except a little falling towards the end. Of how many Angels do we reade in ≈øcriptures, who appeared like men? As Raphael to Tobias, Gabriel, to Zacharie, & the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin; others to Io≈øue, Gedeon, Manue, &c.? What variety of colours in a Rainbow, & a Pigeon's neck? Here ≈øome reflected lyght affects the eye as if it were real colours: & in the other examples, a little conden≈øed ayre lookes like the real body of a man. Examples of this nature myght be multiplyed without end, were it need full: but the≈øe are enough to proue, that our eyes are in many things mi≈øtaken, repre≈øenting things in motion, which ≈øtir not; & in re≈øt others, which moue: shewing ≈øub≈øtance other then it is, & colours where there are none.

As for Hearing, ≈øome raving haue ≈øeemed to heare a con≈øort of mu≈øicke. A per≈øon of my acquaintance was once awakened with an exceeding great noi≈øe, as if guns had ben shot off at his bed ≈øide. Calling to mind, that there was nether Canon, nor any thing el≈øe, neere, which could cau≈øe that va≈øt noy≈øe, he concluded it mu≈øt be ≈øomething in his eare; & picking it, he pulled out a little in≈øect, bred in ≈øome ro≈øes, which the day before he had throwne over the te≈øter of his bed, which falling from them, & creeping into his eare, with the motion of its little tender feete cau≈øed that huge noy≈øe.

Whither the≈øe, & ≈øuch like in≈øtances of the vncertainty of our Sen≈øes, ≈øufficiently proue, that they were not de≈øigned by the Authour of nature, God Almyghty, for in≈øtruments of ≈øciences, or to conveygh new notions into our mind, or only, as Guards, or ≈øentinels, for our ≈øecurity, & pre≈øervation, (the only thing they can be de≈øigned for in Bea≈øts, th√¥ the≈øe haue their Sen≈øes as perfect, as men) I leaue to the judgment of others: as al≈øo to determine,
whither the≈øe examples can ground a judgment in that doubt. what I gather hence, is

That Sen≈øes are often mi≈øtaken, & that even about their proper objects. That the≈øe errours are ≈øometimes corrected by our owne rea≈øon, or di≈øcour≈øe, & ≈øome times by advice, or information from other men. For example: we know that on oare hath a ≈øtrong con≈øi≈øtency of parts, to which tho≈øe of the water yeild, as having no con≈øi≈øtency at all. Whence th√¥ our eyes repre≈øent it, as broken in the water, we conclude their depo≈øition fal≈øe, 1. becau≈øe water cannot breake a ≈øtrong oare gently thru≈øt into it, & 2. becau≈øe if it were broken by the water, it would not be whole, when taken out, as we ≈øee it is. Thus rea≈øon corrects our eyes. By di≈øcour≈øe likewi≈øe we find, that the diameter of the moone is much bigger, then a foote, as our eyes repre≈øent it. Now an illiterate Bumpkin, who knowes not how the tru quantity of a body ≈øeemes le≈ø≈øe, by rea≈øon of its di≈øtance from the eye, heares one, whome he beleiues to be a learned clark, ≈øay, the moone is bigger then all his grounds are, & he beleiues him: & vpon his credit, corrects that errour of his eyes. So he preferres the word of that learned man before his ≈øyght.

4. It is ea≈øy to draw from the≈øe premi≈ø≈øes, the conclu≈øion cheifely intended, viz, that it is rash, & pre≈øumptuous to alleadge, & rely on any ≈øen≈øation contrary to the word of God, or any revealed Truth. For if your rea≈øon, & di≈øcour≈øe, or the Authority of a man, more knowing, & experienced then our ≈øelues are ≈øufficient to make vs frame a judgment different from, or contrary to the depo≈øitions of the mo≈øt perfect of our Sen≈øes, our eyes, with much greater rea≈øon ought we to ≈øu≈øpect their depo≈øitions, nay & reject them, when we find them di≈øagree from what God hath atte≈øted. For J hope the world is not brought as yet by Dogmatizers to ≈øuch a degree of Libertini≈øme, & Athei≈øme, as to ≈øay, that God either can be deceived him ≈øelfe, through ignorance, or can maliciou≈øly deceiue vs. And if the credit of a man be ≈øufficient to reforme the judgments

Wherefore we mu≈øt nether prefer Rea≈øon before Faith, with Socinus: nor [which is wor≈øe] Sen≈øe before Faith, with Dr. Morley; but with S. Paul, & the Church, ≈øubmit both Sen≈øe, & Rea≈øon, to Faith: & let God be tru, & all men lyars.

SECTION VII. How far ≈øen≈øes are ≈øerviceable to Faith?
1. Carte≈øian doubts de≈øtroy ≈øcience, & human ≈øociety.
2. Nature of Faith, as it comprehends divine & humane.

div.p:
1. ALth√¥ I think the Sen≈øes ≈øometimes are, & often may be mi≈øtaken, & for that rea≈øon think we ought to reject their depo≈øitions, when they are contrary to ≈øuch things, as we haue greater rea≈øon to tru≈øt to: yet J am far from the ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe errour of tho≈øe, who ≈øay, no credit at all is du to them: or that by them we cannot be ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øured, that we haue nether hornes, nor a coxcombe on our head, that our no≈øe is nether the bille of a cocke, nor the trunk of an Elephant: or that our Body is fle≈øh,
& not gla≈ø≈øe, or butter. Which is the ≈øentiment of the Authour of the Search of Truth. Carte≈øius teachs vs more, to doubt whither we are awake, or a ≈øleepe, or haue any body at all. Which doubts, if really admitted, & not pretended only, afford an excellent pretext to all Ignoramus jurys: to all malefactours, who may pretend the witne≈ø≈øes are not certain of what they depo≈øe: to all Rebells, & Refractory ≈øubjects, who may alleadge their doubts again≈øt the King's Proclamation: la≈øtly to all knaues, who may pretend ignorance of the promi≈øes, which they haue no mind to keepe. So this Carte≈øian way to knowledge, & certainty, by ca≈øting off all former knowledge, & ≈øen≈øes, as vncertain, lays the Axe at the roote of all Authority, di≈ø≈øolues all bonds of commerce among≈øt men, & is only good to make Scepticks, & Athei≈øts too, ≈øeing it leaues no certain meanes to teach, or learne Faith, & to vnder≈øtand ≈øcripture, or Councils. So that nether Church, nor ≈øtate can ≈øtand, if the≈øe doubts again≈øt the depo≈øitions of Sen≈øes, without any ground to the contrary, be≈øides the general fallibility of our Sen≈øes them≈øelues, be really admitted.

Wherefore when D. Morley often repeates, that we deny all authority to our Sen≈øes, he is either deceived him≈øelf, or deceiues his reader, which is wor≈øe: for we rely on our Sen≈øes, where Rea≈øon, or greater Authority doth not contradict them: of both which J haue giuen examples. So a man ≈øees Titius kill Simpronius, & depo≈øes it vpon oath: his depo≈øition ought to be admitted, notwith≈øtanding all Carte≈øian doubts. So Peter relyes on a promi≈øe of Paul to Pay him within ≈øuch a time, 100. l. Paul is bound to make it good, & Peter may exact it by law.

2. Faith taken generally, as it comprehends Divine, & Humane, is an A≈ø≈øent giuen to a thing as Tru, vpon the credit of another. In the fir≈øt operation of our mind, which con≈øi≈øts of ≈øingle thoughts, called in our ≈øchooles, Simple Apprehen≈øions, there can nether be Truth, nor Falshoode: the≈øe being propertyes of combined thoughts, which are called Propo≈øitions [the≈øe are the ≈øecond operation of our
mind] for they are tru, when conformable to their object: as this The whole is greater, then any part of it. They are fal≈øe, when not conformable to them, as this: Apart of a body is as greate, as the whole. Some adde a third kind of Propo≈øitions, indifferent to Truth, & Falshood: but this is only relating to our minds, which are vncertain, whither they be tru or fal≈øe. But in them≈øelues they are determinately either tru or fal≈øe, & it is as certaine they cannot be otherwi≈øe, as it is certaine, that a thing either is, or is not: it being impo≈ø≈øible, that any thing should be, & not be, at the ≈øame time. That is to ≈øay, two contradictions can nether be tru, nor fal≈øe.

This Truth, or conformity of a Propo≈øition with its object, may be knowne ≈øeveral ways. 1. by its natiue lyght, & ≈øelf evidence, of the thoughts them≈øelues, which when well vnder≈øtood, evidently appeare the ≈øame. For example Two & two are four. Jtem: A ≈øtreyght line is the shortest betwixt two points.

2. By di≈øcour≈øe: as when by the thoughts them≈øelues it doth not appeare how they agree, we compare them with a third. Thus by applying a line to two bodyes, & finding it equal to each ≈øeverally, we conclude they are both of an equall bigne≈ø≈øe, 3. by ≈øen≈øe: as when J ≈øee a man walke, I know he moues. 4. By report of another: as when a freind tells me, he Saw the King a hunting, I take it as a Truth, relying on his word. And this la≈øt way of knowing a thing to be tru, or giving A≈ø≈øent to it, is properly Faith.

3. Two things are nece≈ø≈øary, to make this A≈ø≈øent prudent. 1. That he who relates the thing to me, (the witne≈ø≈øe) be not deceived him≈øelf. 2. That he doth not deceiue me. By rea≈øon of the fir≈øt, we more readily credit an eye-witne≈ø≈øe, than any other, becau≈øe a man is le≈ø≈øe obnoxious to mi≈øtake what he ≈øees, than what he heares, or knows by conjectures. For the ≈øecond, we ea≈øilyer beleiue an hone≈øt man, than any other: and we rather beleiue an hone≈øt man with an Oath, then without it: ≈øeing the≈øe are greater a≈ø≈øurances, that he ≈øpeakes his mind ≈øincerely, & doth not deceiue vs. So an Oath is the ≈øtronge≈øt foundation of human Faith, wherefore
by the Apo≈øtle it is ≈øayd to be To men an End of all ≈øtrife. Heb. 6.16. we will now apply this to Divine Faith.

Nothing can be more certain, than what God averres. Becau≈øe he can nether be deceived, being Omni≈øcient, or knowing all things: nor deceiue vs, by rea≈øon of his goodne≈ø≈øe. So we are never mi≈øtaken in beleiving him. But the a≈ø≈øurance we haue of what any may ≈øays, even vpon Oath, is much le≈ø≈øe. For 1. he may deceived, & think, for example, he ≈øaw the King walking, when it was not the King; but ≈øome other Per≈øon like him. And 2. he may haue an intention to deceiue vs, by making vs beleiue, what he knows to be fal≈øe: whence no man de≈øerues greater credit, than his per≈øonal endowments beare: & to beleiue him further, is blamed in ≈øcripture, He that is hasty to giue credit, is lyght minded. Eccle≈ø. 19.4. All this is expre≈ø≈øed in few words by the Apo≈øtle: Rom. 3.4. God is tru; & every man a lyar.

Both Phylo≈øophers, & Divines enquire, whither the ≈øame thing can be the object of Faith, & Sen≈øes, can be ≈øeene & beleived? & commonly they conclude that it is impo≈ø≈øible. At lea≈øt this ≈øeemes vndoubted of, that, De facto, it is not ≈øoe.

For the Apo≈øtle ≈øays, that Faith is An evidence of things not ≈øeene. Heb. 11.1. & S. Au≈øtin, tr. 68. & 79. in Ioan. Quide≈øt fides? Credere quod non vides. Faith is a Beleife of things, which we do not ≈øee. So that Sen≈øes are ≈øo far from being the Objectum formale, the motiue of our Faith, that it doth not at all depend on them.

4. The Apo≈øtles, being witne≈ø≈øes of the greate≈øt & mo≈øt important truths, that can be, were carefull to per≈øwade their Auditory, 1. that they vnder≈øtood very well the things they preacht: & 2. that they did not alter any thing in the delivery of it. And becau≈øe Eye witne≈ø≈øes are commonly more a≈ø≈øured, than others, they mention that 1. cor. 15.8. He was ≈øeene of me. 2. Pet. 1.16. We haue not followed cunningly devi≈øed fables, when we made knowne vnto you, the power, & coming of our Lord Ie≈øus-Chri≈øt; but were eye witne≈ø≈øes of his Maje≈øty, ‚Äî. This voice, which came from Heauen we heard,
when we were with him in the holy mount. Here are two Sen≈øes alleadged, Seing & Hearing. And the beloved Di≈øciple 1.30 1.1. & 3. Which we haue heard, which we haue ≈øeene with our eyes, which we haue looked vpon, & our hands haue handled of the word of life. ‚Äî That which we haue ≈øeene, & heard, declare we that vnto you. And S. Peter being to choo≈øe a ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to Iudas, required the choice should be made among≈øt tho≈øe, who from the Bapti≈øme till the A≈øcen≈øion adhered to Chri≈øt. Act. 1.21.22. Of the≈øe men, which haue companyed with vs, all the time, that our Lord Ie≈øus went in & out amongst vs, beginning from the Bapti≈øme of Iohn, vnto that ≈øame day, that he was taken vp from vs, must one be ordained to be a witne≈ø≈øe with vs of his Re≈øurrection. And Nicodemus doubting of ≈øomething, which our faviour had told him, Chri≈øt for confirmation of what he ≈øayd, alleadged the like motiue: Joan. 3.11. We ≈øpeake, what we know, & testify what we haue ≈øeene. And S. Luke in the Preface to his gho≈øpel, a≈ø≈øures, he writes, what he received from tho≈øe, who From the beginning were eye witne≈ø≈øes, & mini≈øters of the word, & having a perfect vnder≈øtanding of things, &c.

Whence is evident, that all that mention of the ≈øen≈øes doth not proue, that Faith hath any dependance at all on them; being only alleadged to make the Preachers of the Gho≈øpel more creditable. But the only tru motiue of our Faith, is the Veracity of God: the Preachers of the Gho≈øpel not delivering their owne word; but the word of God: & the Hearers Receiving it not as the word of men; but as it is truly, the word of God. 1. The≈ø. 2.13. This as to the fir≈øt qualification of a witne≈ø≈øe.

As to the ≈øecond, that They would not deceiue others, was evident from the whole life of the Apo≈øtles, free from levity, from vanity, from ≈øelfe intere≈øt, &c. & all the≈øe ≈øtrengthned by ≈øeveral other circum≈øtances, whereof each one ≈øeverally taken had ≈øome force; but taken altogether, they convinced all con≈øidering men, that it was more them morally impo≈ø≈øible, that men ≈øo qualifyed, should wittingly tell a lye, or deceiue willingly their Auditory. All which
things are hinted at in tho≈øe words: 1. The≈ø. 1.5. div.p:
I Do not profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe a common champion, for all Catholicks, that either Attacke Prote≈øtants, or are Attackt by them. Yet I am of opinion, that my Reader will find ≈øomething in my Review of the Argument, to which what is here ≈øayd, will not giue full ≈øatisfaction, probably it will ≈øcarce be brought within canon shot of it. So my Review of this Treati≈øe is a worke of ≈øupererogation, which J vndertake meerely becau≈øe there is occa≈øion

S. Ambro≈øe l. 10. com. in Lucae c. 24. Mirum quomodo ≈øe natura corporea peer impenetrabile Corpus infuderit, invi≈øibili aditu, vi≈øibili con≈øpectu. S. Augustin, Epi≈øt. 3. ad Volu≈øianum: Ip≈øa virtus per inviolatae Matris Virginea vi≈øcera membra infantis eduxit, quae po≈øtea per clau≈øa o≈øtia membra juvenis introduxit. S. Gregory hom. 26. in Evang. Quodomo po≈øt Re≈øurrectionem Corpus Dominicum verum fuit quod clau≈øis januis ad Di≈øcipulos ingredi potuit? Sed ≈øciendum nobis e≈øt, quod divina operatio, ≈øi ratione comprehenditur, non e≈øt admiranilis: nec fides habet meritum, cui humana ratio praehet experimentum. Thus the Apo≈øtle of our Nation. 5. When our lord walked on the ≈øea, Iohn 6.19. for about thirty furlongs, or neere four miles. That walking on the waters was Miraculous from the beginning, for to each part of that fluid & yeilding

3. D. M. p. 5. Aquinas contradicts him≈øelf, when he ≈øays ≈øome Miracles are invi≈øible. For he ≈øays el≈øe where, that name comes from admiration now how can a thing imperceptible to Sen≈øes be the cau≈øe of Admiration?

An≈ø. 2. Arguments drawne from the Etimology of words, are frivolous, & in≈øignificant. Pontifex was named from making, or mending a Bridge. An≈ø. 3 cannot we admire things imperceptible to Sen≈øes? Js not the Vnion hypo≈øtatical an object of Admiration to all Chri≈øtians? Is not God's birth of a Virgin, admirable?
