list.item: 1. Accidents without a ≈øubject.
2. Extention of quantity in a place.
3. A Body in two places.

div.p: 1. D. M. p. 9. Thomas contradicts him≈øelf in other places. For 1. p. q. 90. ar. 2. C. he ≈øayth: An accident hath no being, but as ≈øomething is denominated by it. That it rather belongs to, than is an entity, That its whole being is to be in ≈øomething. Yet he teaches that in the Sacrament Accidents are without a ≈øubject.

Revi≈øor. What difficulty is there, that God should do, what nature cannot? And how greate ≈øoever is the dependance of Accidents on Sub≈øtance why can not God ≈øeparate them, & ≈øupply by his omnipotency, the want of a ≈øubject, as the Prote≈øtants owne he can pre≈øerue Sub≈øtance without Accidents, alth√¥ it needes them very much? The being of an Accident is to Informe, ine≈ø≈øe: & that of a Sub≈øtance, is to recerue information, Sube≈ø≈øe. Now if God can pre≈øerue a Sub≈øtance, without receiving Accidents, why not Accidents, without being received? The≈øe two are correlatiues, tis tru: but Relatiues may haue a being without their terme You will ≈øay, they cea≈øe to be relatiues, when the terme is gon, retaining only an aptne≈ø≈øe to a new relation, when it hath a new terme: & J reply this is ju≈øt what pa≈ø≈øes in our ca≈øe. For the Accidents after Tran≈øub≈øtantiation haue no actual Relation to Sub≈øtance, but an aptne≈ø≈øe to one, when occa≈øion is pre≈øented. And for this rea≈øon Accidents in the Sacrament, are ≈øayd to haue an ex ≈øtence like in ≈øome ≈øort, to ≈øub≈øtance: Habent modum exi≈øtendi ≈øub≈øtantiae Yet it is di≈øtingui≈øht from all Sub≈øtance, by that expre≈ø≈øe, & natural propen≈øion it hath to denominat ≈øub≈øtance, & it ≈øuffers violence till it be re≈øtored to its innate manner of being in a ≈øub≈øtance, as a ≈øtone doth, when it is ≈øu≈øpended in the Ayre.
D. p. q. Aquinas teachs that quantity hath exten≈øion of parts, in re≈øpect of place; yet in the ≈øacrament he ≈øayth it hath none. In which he contradicts him≈øelf.

Revi≈øor. Quantity hath two effects; one in the Sub≈øtance, which it informes: the other in the place, which it fills. The fir≈øt is In genere cau≈øae formalis, as a forme: & this effect of quantity is in Chri≈øt's Body in the ≈øacrament very perfectly, for his ≈øacred Body being aliue, or animated with his rational ≈øoul, it mu≈øt be Corpus organicum which imports a di≈øtinction of parts from one another.

The other effect, as to the place it fills, is In genere cau≈øae efficientis, as an efficient, & actiue cau≈øe, by a certain ela≈øticity, & ≈øpringine≈ø≈øe of the parts of a body, which thru≈øt backe ≈øuch bodyes, as on all ≈øides pre≈ø≈øe vpon it. which by moderne experiences is evident in the Ayre, & in alike manner may be proved of other things. Hence the ≈øame Quantity hath ≈øometimes a greater, ≈øometimes a le≈ø≈øer exten≈øion in order to place, according as the ambient bodyes do more, or le≈ø≈øe, pre≈ø≈øe vpon it, & its ela≈øticity is more, or le≈ø≈øe actiue. Thus in the top of a very hygh hill in Auvergne, askin well ≈øtopt ≈øeemed full of Ayre; & at the bottome of it, where the Athmo≈øphere pre≈øt much, it wanted much of ≈øeeming full. Al≈øo a ball of Bra≈ø≈øe, with a little pin hole, being halfe fild with water, containes it all very well: till by being to a certain degree heated in afire, its ela≈øticity is encrea≈øed, for then the water & Ayre mingled will breake through that narrows pa≈ø≈øage, & fill the chamber with a kind of mi≈øt. Now if a Quantity of fiue foote, for example, by diminishing its Ela≈øticity, or encrea≈øing the pre≈ø≈øures of ambient Bodys, be brought to four, or three feete, why may it not be reduced to two, or one? Or by Divine Power quite ≈øu≈øpending its Elasticity, be brought to an vnconceivable littlene≈ø≈øe of place, which would ≈øcarce de≈øerue that name. If fire, the mo≈øt actiue cau≈øe knowne, had no effect on the three children in the Babilonian furnace, God ≈øu≈øpending its vertu, why cannot God ≈øu≈øpend the actiue vertu of a little Quantity?

Which I do not ≈øay, to demon≈øtrate fully the whole my≈øterious manner of the exi≈øtence of the Body of Chri≈øt, in this Divine Sacrament (that being a thing to be beleived by faith; not to be proved, or even comprehended, & perfectly vnder≈øtood by naturall rea≈øon) but only to diminish the difficulty of the beleife of it, by explicating in ≈øome probable manner a part of the my≈øtery.

You ≈øee, ≈øir, how ea≈øy it is to excu≈øe S. Thomas from the contradiction, you charge him with: for it is no contradiction to ≈øay: A fire well kindled burnes matter combu≈øtible duly applyed: & in the furnace fire did not burne tho≈øe three young men. Both which we know to be tru, one by experience, the other by Revelation, why may not ≈øuch an obvious explication excu≈øe this greate Doctor, from ≈øo shamefull a fault as contradicting him≈øelf is? That all quantity fills ≈øome ≈øpace is a general rule: that in the Sacrament it doth not, is an exception from this rule. Can you not vnder≈øtand how a man without contradicting him≈øelf admits an exception from his Rule?

3. D M. p. 10. La≈øtly Thomas, & all the re≈øt teach, that no other body can be in more places, than one at one time: yet they ≈øay Chri≈øts body in the Sacrament, is in many places at the ≈øame time. Thus they mantain what their church hath defined, though it be with doing violence to all the principles not of Divinity only; but of Nature, ≈øen≈øe, & Rea≈øon: & not without manife≈øt, & manifold contradictions not of one another onely; but even of them≈øelues al≈øo.

Revi≈øor. The contradiction you charge on S. Thomas, & all Catholicks, is that we teach that Christ's body is in two places, at once: & that we deny, that Any other body can be in two places at once. Where your fir≈øt fault, is again≈øt Logick: for you beleiue the≈øe two propo≈øitions to be contradictions, & they are not ≈øoe. For a contradiction is Affirmatio, & negatio eiu≈ødem de eodem, the ≈øame thing mu≈øt be ≈øayd, & denyed of the ≈øame ≈øubject: now here is not the ≈øame ≈øubject: for Chri≈øts body, & other bodys are not the ≈øame. Hence it is no contradiction to ≈øay: Christs body is per≈øonally vnited to the word: and, no other body is per≈øonally vnited to the word.

Your ≈øecond fault is more reproachfull, a lack of ≈øincerity in relating our ≈øentiments. You ≈øay, we teach that No other body, (but that of Chri≈øt) can be in more places than one, at the ≈øame time. Which is ≈øo far from being tru, that I will challenge you, or any other in the world, to produce any one, either Divine, or Philo≈øopher, of the Catholick communion who denyes to Any body a pa≈ø≈øiue capacity of being in two places, when God shall determine, in that ≈øame manner, that he beleiues Chri≈øt's body is in two places. And if I am di≈øproved in this, I am content to be thought the Impo≈øtor. Had you con≈øulted either our Phylo≈øophers, or Divines, or even any of our yearly conclu≈øions, you would haue found in≈øtances enough to correct your mi≈øtake, if it were not affected: which I will not determine. I ≈øay In that ≈øame manner, that he beleiues Christ's body is in two places: becau≈øe I know the Thomi≈øts hold a body cannot be Exten≈øiv√®, Localit√®r, or De≈øinitiv√® in two places, [& the Scoti≈øts hold the contrary] but tho≈øe ≈øame learned men ≈øay the ≈øame of the Body of Christ. So your mi≈øtake is vnexcu≈øable.

Your third fault, is, that Our Doctrine is contrary to all principles of Divinity. I know no other, at lea≈øt no better, Principles of tru Divinity, than Scripture, Tradition, Definitions of the Church, & Fathers. If you know any better, make vs happy by communicating them. Now J am ≈øure our Doctrine is not contrary to the≈øe; nay it is grounded on them all: & this you knew ≈øo well, that you haue carefully avoyded all mention of them, as con≈øcious of your contradicting them all, & fore≈øeing that they are rockes, on which this Sen≈øual Here≈øy would ≈øplit it ≈øelf. Scriptures ≈øays, It is Chri≈øts body: Tradition ≈øays the ≈øame, ≈øo do Fathers, ≈øo doth the Church: ≈øo do we. Not one Egge more like another, than our Doctrine, is to theirs. What violence then do we do, to all the principles of Divinity? But it is not vnu≈øual, that men, who rob, cry Theiues. You know you cannot proue that we oppo≈øe any one principle of Divinity: ≈øo you never attempt it. Yet you would haue it beleived, & Therefore you beg it.

Your fourth fault is, that you blame vs, as faulty, for going in matters of Faith, again≈øt Nature, Sen≈øe, & Rea≈øon. Sir we are Di≈øciples of S. Paul, of him we haue learnt, To ca≈øt downe jmaginations, & every hygh thing, that exalts it ≈øelf again≈øt the knowledge of God, & bring into captivity every thought to the obedience of Chri≈øt. 2. cor. 10.6. This we practice in this, & other matters. If in this we are blameworthy, condemne him, who directs vs to do ≈øo: if you dare not condemne him, you mu≈øt ab≈øolue vs.

Call to mind S. Au≈øtins words, mentioned aboue, in Epi≈øt. ad Volu≈øianum: Si ratio quaeritur, non erit mirabile: ≈øi exemplum po≈øcitur, non erit ≈øingulare. If a rea≈øon be found out, it will cea≈øe to be admirable: if an example be produced, it will not be ≈øingular. We owne it is Admirable, we profe≈ø≈øe it is Singular. So we expect nether Rea≈øon, nor example to confirme vs in the beleife of it. That is, we are nether Socinians, nor Morleyans. Iu≈øt ≈øo we beleiue the ≈øame Chri≈øt to be borne of a virgin, th√¥ nether Rea≈øon, nor experience confirme it.

Yet out of ≈øome other places of ≈øcripture joyned together, it appeares, that Chri≈øt's body hath been in two places, at the ≈øame time. For we learne out of Ephe≈ø. 4.10. that He a≈øcended vp far aboue all Heavens: whence Heb. 7.26 he is ≈øayd To be Hygher then the Heavens. And Act. 13.21. we reade: Whome the Heavens mu≈øt receiue, till the time of re≈øtitution of all things: that is till the vniver≈øal Re≈øurrection, he mu≈øt remaine aboue the Heavens. Yet he was ≈øeene by S. Paul, 1. Cor. 15.8. & Act. 9. Therefore he was in two places at the ≈øame time: In Heaven, & aboue the Heavens, as the ≈øcripture ≈øays: & neere the Earth, otherwi≈øe the Apo≈øtle could nether haue ≈øeene his Body, nor heard his voice.
You begin pag. 11. a long di≈øcour≈øe about My≈øteryes. Which being nothing to the purpo≈øe, I leaue it, as I find it: & pa≈ø≈øe to the your 19. page, where I find ≈øomething in which I am concerned.

div.head: SECTION XVI. Tran≈øub≈øtantiation is a Miracle.
div.p: MY rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it is a worke not only Be≈øides, or Aboue; but Contrary to ≈øecond cau≈øes. Therefore it is a Miracle. The illation is evident, as being from the definition, to the thing defined. Rev. Here you ≈øerue vp againe your cold cabbadge: which how in≈øipid they were at fir≈øt, we haue Seene, now we nau≈øeate them. Yet for four pages you afford vs no other foode.

D. M. p. 23. God never workes a Miracle, but for ≈øome greate, & good End, which cannot be obtained without it, for God doth nothing in vaine. Now ≈øuch a Miracle would be to no purpo≈øe, for Chri≈øt ≈øayd the flesh profiteth nothing.

Revi≈øor. The Apo≈øtles, the Fathers, the Church, the Faith full all over the world had & haue a far different opinion of the ≈øacramental Communion of the Body & Bloud of Chri≈øt, than you haue. S. Paul makes v≈øe of that con≈øideration to moue men to try them≈øelues before they approach the Divine Table: lea≈øt by receiving it vnworthily, they become guilty of the Body & Bloud of Chri≈øt. S. Cyril of Hieru≈øalem, ≈øays that by it we are Chri≈øtophori, Bearers of Christ, jtem Con≈øanguinei his kin≈ømen. S. Chri≈øo≈øtome: yOu de≈øire to ≈øee Chri≈øt, to heare his voice, to touch the hemme of his garment: more is granted to you; that you eate him, &c. Againe when de≈øcribes a Prei≈øt at the Altar, with quires of Angels round about him the Heavens open over his head, God the holy gho≈øt cooperating with him, God the ≈øon in his hands to be offred to the Eternal Father, who is aboue expecting to receiue that mo≈øt gratefull offering, doth all this avayle nothing? Was the centurion moved with the con≈øideration of his owne vnworthine≈ø≈øe, being to receiue Chri≈øt vnder his roofe; & is our Faith ≈øo dead, as to be in≈øen≈øible when he vouch≈øafes to come into our bo≈øomes? What can, if this doth not, ≈øtir vp in vs ≈øorrow for having offended Almyghty God: Faith in him, whome we beleiue pre≈øent: Hope, that he, who hath giuen him≈øelf vnto vs, will not, can not refu≈øe vs any thing. Be≈øides acts of Devotion, of Adoration, of Humility, of Zeale, &c.

All which if you e≈øteeme incon≈øiderable, & to Profit nothing, I de≈øire you to tell me, what doth profit in the way of vertu? You will ≈øay Faith. And J will an≈øwer we haue that as well, as you, & that quickned, & ≈øtrengthned by the con≈øideration of him really pre≈øent, who is both Authour, & Object, or la≈øt end, the Œõ. & Œ©. of our Faith.

Jn fine S. Eucherius ≈øayd: Tria ≈øibi Deus struxit tabernacula, &c. God hath ≈øet vp for him≈øelf three tents, the Synagogue, the Chri≈øtian
Church, & Heaven. In the fir≈øt, there is nothing but Types of things hoped for: in the la≈øt, Sub≈øtance without any Types: in the Chri≈øtian Church Sub≈øtance vnder Types: That ≈øame Chri≈øt, who was figured to the Iews, & is cleerely ≈øeene, & enjoyed by the Ble≈ø≈øed in Heaven, being really pre≈øent vnder Types on our Altars. And you Prote≈øtants by denying this pre≈øence of Chri≈øt, in this Divine Sacrament, what do you, but degrade your Communion from the dignity of a Sacrament of the new law, & bring it to the condition of a jewish rite, of a ba≈øe Beggarly element.

But The flesh profiteth nothing, ≈øay you. I grant it, if it be taken carnally, & without ≈øpirit, or Faith, without di≈øcerning betwixt that, & other Bodily food; not otherwi≈øe.
