D. M. p. 24. 25. Lastly there can be no ≈øuch Miracle, as Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, becau≈øe all Miracles are po≈ø≈øible; Tran≈øub≈øtantiation is impo≈ø≈øible. And you ≈øend vs to ≈øee this proved in D. Whitaker Bishop Morton & Mr. Chillingworth, who shew ≈øay you that this implyes contradiction, & ≈øuch things cannot be done: nay it would argue rather an impotency, than omnipotency in God to doe ≈øuch things.

Revi≈øor. You had done vs applea≈øure, & Prote≈øtants would haue thought your time well ≈øpent, in producing Rea≈øons to proue this implicancy; & not to ≈øend vs, & them on this wild goo≈øe chac√©, to find what tho≈øe learned men ≈øay in this point. The meane while, what you haue ≈øayd, proues nothing: & the beleife of Tran≈øubstantiation remaines firme: & God, and his Church Tru.
D. M. p. 27. There is therefore no ≈øuch Miracle as Tran≈øub≈øtantiation; it being not onely an v≈øele≈ø≈øe thing, if it were ≈øo; but an impo≈ø≈øible thing, that it should be lo.

Revi≈øor: That Tran≈øub≈øtantiation is a Miracle, is a thing ≈øo evident to Rea≈øon, that J never feare to ≈øee the Rea≈øons for it an≈øwered. That it is V≈øele≈ø≈øe, & impo≈ø≈øible, you ≈øay, but you will never be able to per≈øuade the fir≈øt; to any pious man, nor the ≈øecond, to any learned man.

div.head: THE FOVRTH BOOK. A REVISION OF D. M.'s ANSWER TO Mr CRESSEY'S LETTER. HIS SERMON BEFORE THE KING. HIS LETTER TO HER ROYAL HYGHNESSE. ET HIS LETTER TO A PREIST.
THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THe≈øe three pieces, containing not many doctrinal Points controverted betwixt the two Churchs of Rome, & England, will not detaine me long, in reviewing your judgment declared in them, e≈øpecially con≈øidering that a greate part is per≈øonal, of Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey, the Gun powder Plotters, & her R. H. which kind of things, whither tru, or fal≈øe, may be let pa ≈øe without any prejudice to the Catholick Caeu≈øe. For Per≈øonal ≈øanctity of all Catholicks ≈øpread all over the world, is a thing to be wisht; not hoped for. And alth√¥ ≈øome faults, even of the fir≈øt magnitude could be proved vpon ≈øome of them, yet that ought no more to moue any man to abandon the Communion of the Church now, than it did to abandon it in the Apo≈øtles times, when ≈øome of her children were Detractors, Gluttons, Ince≈øtuous, Contentious, Proud, & Avaritious men, as may be ≈øeene in S. Paul's Epi≈øtles. In the≈øe, indeed, mention is made of a Church free from ≈øpot, & wrinkle: & that we hope for in Heaven. But at pre≈øent there are in the net, good & bad fish: in the feild, Corne & Darnel: in the barne,
wheate, & Chaffe: in the hou≈øe, Ve≈ø≈øells to honour, & to dishonour. Among≈øt the virgins, ≈øome foolish: among≈øt the Apo≈øtles, a Iudas; an I≈ømael in Abraham's family: an E≈øau, in I≈øaacs, a Ruben in Iacob's: an Ab≈øalom, in David's: an Adam in the terre≈øtrial Paradice, & a Lucifer in the Cele≈øtial. All which bad men did nether excu≈øe a ≈øeparation from the Church, in which they lived, nor prejudice the re≈øt, who did not approue, or abette the ≈øins: as the Church hath long ≈øince declared again≈øt the Donati≈øts. We profe≈ø≈øe we beleiue the Sanctity of the Catholick Church, which con≈øi≈øts in her Doctrine, her Laws, her Rites, & many of her children; not all: And it is the goodne≈ø≈øe of God to make vs partakers of all the good workes, which any one doth; but not of the bad: For we beleiue a Communion of Saints; not of ≈øinners; of merits; not of offen≈øes. So the guilt of ≈øin is confined to the per≈øon ≈øinning: but the merits of vertuous actions ≈øpreades to all the faithfull who are in the ≈øtate of grace. Wherefore we ought not to think the wor≈øe of the Church, for any fault committed by any of her children, ≈øeing she nether teaches, nor commands, nor approues it. But the Prote≈øtant Church cannot ≈øo ea≈øily cleare her ≈øelfe from ≈øuch ≈øpots, as the ≈øins of her children leaue: her Doctrine of the impo≈ø≈øibility of God's Commandments, that we are nether the better for good, nor the wor≈øe for bad actions (which are nether meritorious, nor demeritorious in the praede≈øtinate) & of Evangelical liberty, the roote of all Sedition, & Rebellion in Church & State, &c. The≈øe I ≈øay, & the like, having beene taught by ≈øame of her children, & never condemned by her, make her an≈øwearable for all ≈øorts of ≈øins, which are but the natural ≈øequels, of tho≈øe Premi≈ø≈øes, effects of tho≈øe cau≈øes, fruits of that tree, which the fir≈øt Prote≈øtants planted, & their followers water, & cherish. In Catholicks a bad life is contrary to Catholick Doctrine & laws; in Prote≈øtants, it is a natural ≈øequel of both.

J do not ≈øay this, to excu≈øe any fault, with rea≈øon charged vpon the per≈øons mentioned (except the gun powder plotters) or to
fore≈øtall my Readers judgment, in favour of the Church, if tho≈øe accu≈øed should be really found guilty. There is no cau≈øe for ≈øuch an Apology. The faults alleadged again≈øt Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey are at the wor≈øt indi≈øcreete expre≈ø≈øions of edjous things which he thought tru, & D. M. thinks not ≈øo. And her R. H. did shew in effect, that no Wordly con≈øideration should moue her to profe≈ø≈øe a Religion, of which in her con≈øcience she was not. Of which more hereafter. Who, but Athei≈øts, & Libertins, can blame this? Which is only a preferring Heaven to Earth, Eternity to time, the ≈øoul to the body, God to man: & the Peace of a good con≈øcience, before the reproach of ≈øome bad men. Tho≈øe who think all Religions indifferent, & that the King is to determine which we are to follow, the Hobbians, may blame this; but not a Di≈øciple of Chri≈øt, & his Apo≈øtles.

div.head:
SECTION XVII. Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey excu≈øed.
1. Whither the Kingdome may be ≈øayd to haue taken the Covenant?
2. Whither the K. was the only ≈øufferer for his Religion?
3. Many of the Prote≈øtant Clergy renounc't their Dignityes?
4. Whither the Clergy ≈øuffred for their Loyalty, or their Religion?
5. Of the Actings of the English Prote≈øtant Clergy in the troubles.
div.p: 1. D. M. p. 7. It is fal≈øe & injurious to ≈øay, that the Presbiterians did con≈øtrain the whole kingdome to forswear their Religion: for it mu≈øt be the whole Kingdomes taking, & not the Pre≈øbiterians impo≈øing generally of the Covenant, that must proue this a≈ø≈øertion.

Revi≈øor. You take Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey's words in a very ≈øtrict ≈øen≈øe, that
you may accu≈øe them, & condemne him. Yet I think in good Phylo≈øophy, & divinity too, Propo≈øitions In materi√¢ contingenti, alth√¥ they ≈øeeme Vniver≈øal, are not ≈øuch, but only Indefinite. For example: Philip. 2.21. All ≈øeeke their owne; not the things, which are of Ie≈øus-Chri≈øt. & Tit 1.12. The Cretans are always lyars, evil Bea≈øts, ≈ølow bellyes. The≈øe Propo≈øitions are as to their forme Vniver≈øal, the fir≈øt with a di≈øtributiue particle to Per≈øons, All: the ≈øecond with alike particle, of time, Always. Yet nether are truly Vniver≈øal: not the fir≈øt, for nether S. Paul, nor ≈øeveral of the Apo≈øtles then aliue, Sought their owne. In alike manner among≈øt the Cretans ≈øome were very good, ≈øincere, & vertuous men. Such Propo≈øitions are frequent in common di≈øcour≈øe: v. c. All Spainards are Graue: All French men civil. All Italians cautious: All young men rash: All women talkatiue: All old men moro≈øe. &c. Which are taken as tru, becau≈øe commonly they are ≈øo, taken Indefinit√®. But taken as Vniver≈øals, they are fal≈øe, ≈øeing ≈øeveral in≈øtances can be brought, in which they are not tru: & greate warine≈ø≈øe is nece≈ø≈øary in applying any one of them, to particulars. This is my fir≈øt An≈øwer.

Another is, that the Kingdome by an ordinary figure is taken for the governing part of it: ≈øo what is decreed by that, may be ≈øayd to be decreed by the Kingdome. Which is tru, th√¥ ≈øome of this part oppo≈øe it. Thus a Peace, or Truce is ≈øayd to be made by the Republick Of Venice, v. c. when the Senate decrees it, or when the major part of Senators re≈øolue it, alth√¥ ≈øome Senators oppo≈øe it, & are for war. Livy. Vbi ≈øemel decretum erit, omnibus id etiam, quibus ante di≈øplicuerat, pro bono, atque vtili foedere erit defendendum. Plinius l. 6. Epi≈øt. 13. Quod pluribus placuit, omnibus tenendum. Dioni≈øius Halicarna≈ø≈øaeus: Parendum his, quae pars maior cen≈øuerit. Even tho≈øe who di≈ølike a decree before it be made, are bound to approue it, after it is made. Provided it containe nothing again≈øt Con≈øcience. Indeed we ≈øee in all A≈ø≈øemblyes, where things are carryed by plurality of votes, all, even the NOES, are bound to approue the order, vnle≈ø≈øe in ≈øome ca≈øes, when they are admitted to a Prote≈øtation.
Now the major part of the then Gouvernours of the Nation, or Kingdome decreed the taking of the Covenant: & the major & more con≈øpicuous part of the ≈øubjects may be ≈øayd to haue admitted that decree, alth√¥ very many, con≈øiderable both for number, & quality, by ≈øome indu≈øtry shifted off the taking of it. so the Kingdome may in ≈øome ≈øort be ≈øayd To impo≈øe the Covenant: & al≈øo To take it. Thus we ≈øay, that England changed its Religion ≈øuch a yeare: th√¥ a very greate number at that time did not admit of any change. And we may ≈øay that the Oaths are impo≈øed vpon, & taken by, the Kingdome: th√¥ ≈øeveral refu≈øe them. Were not Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey a Papi≈øt, I beleiue either of the≈øe an≈øwers would ≈øuffice.

2. D. M. p. 8. His ≈øecond crime, is his ≈øaying The King was almo≈øt the only man, who remained ≈øo con≈øtant to his Religion, as to hazard for it the lo≈ø≈øe of his e≈øtate & life too. This is fal≈øe, ≈øay you, for many thou≈øands did the ≈øame.

Revi≈øor. In the ruin of others there was a complicancy of cau≈øes, which procured it: loyalty to their King, hatred to their per≈øons for fyghting again≈øt them, their e≈øtates &c. For Naboth was not the only man, who lo≈øt his life, for his inheritance. Now there was a time, when the demands of the Presbiterians ≈øeemed not intollerable to the King, who only ≈øtucke at the de≈øtruction of the Bishops. So Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey myght ≈øay, he was Almo≈øt the only man who ≈øuffred on the ≈øcore of his prote≈øtant Epi≈øcopacy. I haue not heard of very many ruined, & killed, becau≈øe they Would not renounce the Bishops. Nether did the Rebels v≈øe to ≈øay: Renounce Bishops, or we will hang you. Several ≈øayd, renounce Popery, or we will kill you: & many were killed by the Rebells for not complying. But to no Prote≈øtant was giuen ≈øuch ≈øowre ≈øawce, that J heard of.

3. D. M. p. 8. Thirdly he ≈øays: Several of the wi≈øe≈øt, & learnede≈øt of the English Clergy were content to buy their ≈øecurity with a voluntary degrading of them≈øelues, from their offices, & Titles. Which, ≈øay you, is injurious to the Bishops.

Rev. Why the Bishops should be vnder≈øtood in that propo≈øition,
J know not. In our Canon law, when only an inferiour, & generical degree is named, in odious thing's (as this it in your eye) the ≈øuperiour, & particular is not comprehended. [vide C. Sedes Apo≈øtol. de Re≈øcriptis, & the glo≈ø≈øe vpon it] now Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey mentions only The Clergy, which is the lowe≈øt & mo≈øt common degree. Wherefore nether Bishops, nor Deanes, nor any Per≈øon in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Dignity mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be comprehended. What then doth offend you, in this Propo≈øition? Did not ≈øeveral of the English Clergy become Catholicks? Did not the≈øe degrade them≈øelues From the offices, & titles which they enjoyed in the Church of England? Could they retaine them remaining Catholicks? Did not ≈øome of the English Clergy yeild to the ≈øtreame, & comply with the times? Did not ≈øome beare armes? Did not one, & he a Metrapolitan, lay a≈øide his Crozier, & take vp a ≈øword? Did not all the≈øe degrade them≈øelues? May not the≈øe different ≈øort of De≈øertors, be named Several of the English Clergy? Were it not in the book of a Papist, probably they myght ≈øo, & the book pa≈ø≈øe without offen≈øe.

But Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey ≈øays, that he meanes the Vniver≈øality of the Bishops, who ≈øeemed to degrade them≈øelues, by not filminating any cen≈øure again≈øt the Rebells. An≈øwer: If he doth ≈øo, he ≈øays more, than what was nece≈ø≈øary to make good his fir≈øt Propo≈øition. You ≈øay that cen≈øures are not a Nece≈ø≈øary duty of a Bishop. So you both agree that To cen≈øure is a duty of a Bishop, in time & place: yet with this difference, that you think it is not a Nece≈ø≈øary duty of a Bishop; & he thinks it is: doth this diver≈øity of Thoughts make him Criminal? E≈øpecially being conformable to ≈øcripture. 2. Trin. 4.2. Reproue, Rebuke, exhort. Tit. 1.13 Rebuke them sharpely. Did not Chri≈øt giue power to bind, as well as to loo≈øen? To retaine, as well as to relea≈øe? To shut, as well as to open? If on pre≈ø≈øing occa≈øions they neglect the v≈øe of that Power To bind, retaine, shut, is it not as much as to renounce that Power? & if they renounce that, do they retaine the other? Is not Epi≈øcopacy one individual Power?

I de≈øire you to shew me any one Catholick country, where ≈øuch
a Rebellion hapned, & all the Bishops remained ≈øilent. By what doth Chri≈øt di≈øtinguish a Pa≈øtor from a Mercenary? Joan. 10. The fir≈øt ≈øees a Wolf coming, & expo≈øes his life, for the defence of his flock: the later ≈øeing the wolf coming, runs away, & lets the wolf worry his ≈ølocke at Plea≈øure. Which of the≈øe two did our English Bishops imitate? But J leaue the application to the Reader.

But what can you alleadge to excu≈øe this ≈øilence in ≈øuch an occa≈øion, as would make even the dumbe ≈øon of Crae≈øus ≈øpeake? you haue three motiues: The fir≈øt is, that it was not ≈øea≈øonable. But doth not S. Paul command that it be done even Out of ≈øea≈øon?

The ≈øecond: that it would haue done no good. But that was De futuro contingenti. How ever in a de≈øperate ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, is it not better to apply an vncertain remedy, than none at all? Would any one haue thought that the Layty had complyed with their duty to ≈øerue the King in his wars, if they should haue remained at home, & ≈øayd, Our fyghting for the King will do no Good?

The third: you would not tempt God, nor expo≈øe your order to their malice, who myght extinguish it. The others are but pretended; this is the tru rea≈øon: here the shoo wrings: you thought it good ≈øleeping in a whole skin, & were de≈øirous to keepe your mather's ≈øons out of harmes way. Indeed you would ≈øecure your per≈øons; not your order: for the Rebells had before vowed to roote out your degree; ≈øo that could not be brought into greater danger, than it was in. Wherefore your feare was for your dearly beloved per≈øons.

D. M. p. q. His 4. crime is ≈øaying: that Though many of the Clergy ≈øuffred, in extremity, yet it was not properly with an eye to their Religion; but to their fidelity, & loyalty to their Prince. A bold & vncharitable A≈ø≈øertion.

Revi≈øor. Why ≈øo? 1. Becau≈øe ≈øays the Doctor, they did not tell him ≈øo. An≈øwer: the factious Rebells did tell him ≈øo, declaring they did not per≈øecute for Religion; but for the ≈øecurity of the ≈øtate. Name any Prote≈øtant Par≈øon, hanged for being ≈øuch. Dr. Hewit was executed for ether real, or pretended crimes again≈øt the ≈øtate; not for Religion. So the re≈øt.

Your other rea≈øon is becau≈øe Loyalty is a point of your Religion. An≈øwer: then Su≈øan is innocent: & all M. Cre≈ø≈øey's fault comes to this, that he thought ≈øome crimes again≈øt the ≈øtate, were not again≈øt Religion. And if this be a crime, there are ≈øo many, & ≈øo greate offenders, that you will ≈øcarce find a Iury to pa≈ø≈øe vpon them.
D. M. p. q. I think tho≈øe Martyrs who ≈øuffer in defen≈øe of the V. commandment, as well as of any other.
Rev. You will I hope find a place in your catalogue of Martyrs for tho≈øe Papi≈øts, & Ie≈øuits, who cho≈øe rather to dye, than To beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe.

5. What motiues the Regicides may haue had to leaue vnmole≈øted ≈øome ob≈øcure Par≈øons, is to me as vncertain, as what you ≈øay p. 14. is improbable, Viz, that it was Out of ≈øeare of their intere≈øt, & reputation in the countryes where they lived. They had cut downe the ≈øtately Cedar, & would they ≈øticke at a shrub? They cut off the Head of your Church, & would they feare the toe, or paring a nayl? They pulled downe King & Nobles, the primate & his Brethren: & would they be awed by a country Par≈øon, ≈øcarce knowne even by name fiue miles from the place of his re≈øidence? To morrow I may beleiue this; not to day.

D. M. p. 17. Providence ≈øeemes to haue ≈øuffred, that tho≈øe heroical Confe≈ø≈øors should be ejected out of their ≈øtations, that being di≈øper≈øt over the Nation, they myght ≈øow the ≈øeedes of Loyalty, & Truth.

Rev. Very pretty! As if the Hay of a greate medow, were Di≈øper≈øt, by being gathered into ≈øtackes, or the Atlandick Ocean, by ruming into halfe a dozen Fish-ponds. What corner in all the Kingdome, without ≈øome of your mini≈øtry before the troubles? How then did this my≈øterious Di≈øper≈øion ≈øpread them? ≈øome of them travelled, it is tru, but haply as many did ≈øo before: & what Seeds did they ≈øow abroade? You your ≈øelf were ≈øo wary, as not to ≈øpeake of Religion, till you had a Ie≈øuits hand & word, that it would not be ill taken. A broade then you did not ≈øow tho≈øe ≈øeedes. Did you ≈øow them in England? who ≈øowed the Seedes of Trea≈øon, & falshood,
of which there was ≈øuch ≈øtore, that it overrun the Nation, & are not as yet weeded out? Were the Mini≈øters negligent in ≈øowing tho≈øe good ≈øeedes before the war? Or was their labour, & indu≈øtry lo≈øt? And how was it so ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull after the wars, that it should be a work of Providence? But you thought it honourable, that Providence should appeare in the concernes of your Ministry: ≈øo you bring it in, without well con≈øidering to what intent, & purpo≈øe.

5. D. M. p. 18. Begins to excu≈øe the Bishops neglect of Excommunication all the time of the troubles. Vpon which I aske him ≈øome que≈øtions: Haue not the Bishops Power to excommunicate? Js not that Power to be v≈øed again≈øt obdurate ≈øinners? Were there none ≈øuch from 1640. till 1650? Sure there were. How comes this cen≈øure to be forgotten? The Parliament, ≈øay you p. 21. could not be excommunicated. Ryght; but the Per≈øons in, & of the Parliament myght: & if the cen≈øure did not bring them to their wits, nor re≈øtore them to their duty, it would haue fryghted many well meaning men, who adhered to the others innocently. Which is one effect of cen≈øures. 1. Trin. 5.20. Vt caeteri timorem habeant.
D. M. p. 22. We would not ca≈øt our Pearls vnto swine, (nor our holy things to dogs p. 26.) nor expo≈øe Chri≈øt to contempt, who ≈øayth, who ≈øo ever de≈øpi≈øeth you, de≈øpi≈øeth me.

Rev. A pretty pretext for all hen-harted Prelates! The Apo≈øtles, & Fathers were of a far different opinion, let one ≈øpeake for all: Non calcatur qui per≈øecutionem patitur; ≈øed qui per≈øecutionem timendo infatuatur. Aug. l. 1. de ≈øerm. D. in mon. c. 6. Heis not de≈øpi≈øed, who ≈øuffers per≈øecution but who through Feare of per≈øecution is infatuated, ≈øo as to neglect his duty. Had the Apo≈øtles, & primitiue Bishops, been ≈øo timorou≈øly prudent, Pagani≈øme had never been de≈øtroyed. Semen est ≈øanguis Christianorum ≈øays Tertullian: Plures efficimur, quoties metimur. Our Bloud is ≈øeed: our number encrea≈øes, by our being mowed downe with your ≈øwords. One graine falls, & hundreds grow vp: One Chri≈øtian is martyred, & thou≈øands of Pagans embrace his faith: & the remnant honour Chri≈øt, & his Vicegerents, even
when they per≈øecute them. But this le≈ø≈øon is not learnt in the Protestant Church.

D. M. p. 22. Thirteene Bishops made a trial of their Authority, when they made a ≈øolemn & publick. Prote≈øtation again≈øt the forcible keeping of them out of the Hou≈øe of Peeres, & were for that impeached of Hygh Trea≈øon, & clapt vp in the Tower.

Rev. What is this to the purpo≈øe? Is Prote≈øtation an Epi≈øcopal Act? Cannot meere lay men enter a Prote≈øtation? Is your ≈øeate in the hou≈øe of Peeres of Divine Ryght? Shew the canon of a General Council, or a text of Scripture, that ground either of the≈øe two things. If you can shew none, no wonder the thing should not ≈øucceede, which is not of your Eccle≈øia≈øtical Function. But how comes that concerne for your ≈øeate in Parliament, to be greater than for all other things, how ≈øacred ≈øoever? You ≈øee Faith de≈øtroyed by Here≈øy, & you are ≈øilent: the Church torne in pieces by Schi≈ømes, & you are ≈øilent: the Royal Power vndermined by Factions, the King's ≈øacred per≈øon endangered by Seditions, & affronted by In≈øolent varlets, & ≈øouls poy≈øoned with damnable opinions, & you are ≈øilent. You are debarred ≈øitting in the hou≈øe of Peeres, & you cry out ≈øo loud, as to provoke the Rebells to shut you vp in a Cage. Js this ≈øeate of greater importance, than ≈øouls, than the King's per≈øon, than Royal Authority, than the Church, than Faith?
D. M. p. 24. The Bishops thought they were obliged not to draw that sword of Excommunication, to cut nothing but the Ayre with it, or by striking on a Rocke, to blunt, or breake the Edge of it.

Rev. A ≈øtraw is as good, as ≈øuch a ≈øword, which mu≈øt ≈øtrike only the Ayre, or it will fly in pieces. Oh, but we mu≈øt not ≈øtrike Rockes. Are then all the children of your Church as in≈øen≈øible of your cen≈øures, as a Rocke, of the ≈øtroke of a ≈øword? If ≈øo: who≈øe is the fault, but yours, who haue the breeding of them?

D. M. p. 25. By Excommunication they had expo≈øed not only their Per≈øons; but their Order it ≈øelf to be ruined: for who can tell, whither tho≈øe, who impri≈øoned ≈øome for the Prote≈øtation, would not haue taken
away their liues, if they had interdicted the hou≈øes of Parliament, and excommunicated their adherents. And then what would haue become of the Epi≈øcopal Order it ≈øelf of our Church? Rome would giue vs no Bishops, Lutherans & Calvini≈øts can giue none: other Churchs are too far off. Tarbox.

Revi≈øor. Did I not know your intention, I should think you prevaricated, your rea≈øons are ≈øo far from giving ≈øatisfaction to a Chri≈øtian, ≈øo contrary to what hath been practiced. Nothing, but temporal motiues, & humane re≈øpects in all your di≈øcour≈øe. Was not the whole Catholick nay Chri≈øtian Church, in as greate danger when all the Bishops in the world were in Hieru≈øalem? And did this make them be ≈øilent? Quite contrary, they re≈øolved to preach on, & be≈øeeched God to confirme tem in this re≈øolution. Behold their threatnings, ≈øayd they Act. 4.29. & grant vnto thy ≈øervants, that with all boldne≈ø≈øe, they ≈øpeake thy word.

D. M. p. 29. We think the Power of Excommunication in the Church to be more then either a Political, a Parliamentary, or a meerly Eccle≈øia≈øtical con≈øtitution, as being an Ordinance, & In≈øtitution neither of the State, or of the Church; but of Chri≈øt him≈øelf.

Rev. It is not worth the while, to examin whence you haue it, when many doubt whither you haue it at all: & this neglect of v≈øing it, in ≈øuch vrgent occa≈øions, confirmes them in that doubt. The ≈øame of other que≈øtious, which pa. 29. You propo≈øe: why the Pope did excommunicate Henry VIII. Why not Charles V. Which are nothing to our purpo≈øe. J will only, ≈øay that if the Pope had no better, nor other grounds, than you alleadge, his ca≈øe is hard to be excu≈øed.

D. M. p. 32. Cre≈ø≈øey May confe≈ø≈øe truly, that this whole pa≈ø≈øage was put into his Book by another hand, without his knowledge, & that as he was forced to owne it at fir≈øt, ≈øo he was not permitted to retract, or correct it, in his ≈øecond edition.
Rev. Here are three odious Accu≈øations. 1. Again≈øt the Benedictins, of corrupting another man's workes, making him ≈øay, what he never ≈øayd.
The 2. again≈øt Mr. Cre≈ø≈øey of owning a thing as his owne, which he knew was not his owne; & was to boote fal≈øe.

The 3 again≈øt them all againe, for not permitting that vntruth to be corrected: whereas Mr Cre≈ø≈øey ≈øays expre≈ø≈øely He would haue corrected them, but his corrections come too late to the printer. He ≈øent them than to the printer, & this, he would not have done, but by con≈øent of his ≈øuperiours. Wherefore they con≈øented to that correction: contrary to what you ≈øay.

The meane while the≈øe Crimes are charged by you vpon that ancient graue order, & not a word of proofe offred. I will not ≈øay they are Calumnyes; but J de≈øire you to Act the God father, & giue them convenient names.

div.head:
SECTION XVIII. Revi≈øion of the Sermon nou. 5.
1. Fe≈øtiual days for Thanks givimg good; yet ≈øometimes abu≈øed.
2. That of the 5. of nou. notoriou≈øly.
3. No ≈øeditious Doctrines in the Church of Rome.
4. Of the gunpowder Plotters.
5. Of the penal Laws again≈øt Papi≈øts.
div.p: 1. TO returne thanks to Almyghty God, for the Benefits received of him, e≈øpecially when they are greate, & ≈øignal deliveryes, is a duty enjoined by the law of nature: & that ≈øome ≈øingular favours should be acknowledged with annual ≈øolemnityes, is pre≈øcribed both in the old, & new law. Such were in the old, the Pha≈øe, the Phurim, the Encoenia, the New moones, & the Sabboth. In the new, Chri≈øt ma≈ø≈øe, Ea≈øter, with ≈øuntide, & the ≈øundays.

That the≈øe Anniver≈øary Fea≈øts were gratefull to God, when duly kept, is evident, ≈øeing he commanded them; exacted their being
kept: checked, & punisht ≈øuch as broke, or prophaned them, by any ≈øervile worke. Yet that they were ≈øometimes offen≈øiue to him, is as evident as any thing in Scripture. Amos 5.21. I hate, I de≈øpi≈øe your fea≈øt days, & I will not ≈ømell in your ≈øolemne A≈ø≈øemblyes. And Amos 8.10. I will turne your Fea≈øts into mourning. And Malachy 2.3. I will corrupt your ≈øeede, & ≈øpread dung vpon your faces, even the dung of your ≈øolemne Feasts, & it shall take you away with it. There is then dung in ≈øolemne Fea≈øts, for which God hates, & de≈øpi≈øes them: for which he will turne them into mourning, which he will ≈øpread on men's faces, & de≈øtroy them: as well as Flowers or Fruit gratefull to God, & men. What is this Dung? What the Fruit, or Flowers?

The Fea≈øts are as plea≈øant as Flowers, or Fruit, when they are ≈øpent in con≈øidering the danger men were in, their inability to avoyde it, & Gods mercys, in di≈øcovering, & di≈øappointing it. Then than king God, for his helpe in over coming it, & praying him to continu his Protection. To make them≈øelues worthy of this Ble≈ø≈øing, men mu≈øt be ≈øorry for their offences, & re≈øolue not to offend againe. The≈øe Fea≈øts ≈øo kept would entayle the like Ble≈ø≈øings vpon vs. But they become as odious as Dung, when they are occa≈øions not to pray≈øe God; but cur≈øe his ≈øervants: when men, in them, in lieu of magnifying his mercy, provoke his ju≈øtice, & de≈øerue the mi≈øcheif they haue e≈øcaped by vncharitable invectives again≈øt jnnocents, to ≈øatisfy their Pa≈ø≈øion. What is this but to turne God's Ble≈ø≈øings into cur≈øes: to dry vp the fountaine of his mercy; & ≈øtir vp his Anger: & to draw vpon their heads tho≈øe, or greater punishments, than tho≈øe they e≈øcaped? In fine, to make them≈øelues vnworthy of his Protection?

2. How little Fruit, & what a prodigious quantity of this Dung is found in your Gun powder ≈øolemnity, is evident to any man, who ≈øees the ≈øermons made on that occa≈øion. This, which J now Review, containes 37. pages: yet all it containes of the delivery from the plot it ≈øelf, myght be ≈øayd in one. The re≈øt (excepting ≈øome commonly knowne Truths at the beginning, as that There is a God, &c.) is ≈øpent in charging that horrid plot on Per≈øons certainly, or at lea≈øt
probably jnnocent, & our Religion it ≈øelfe. Now if you, D. Morley, one of the mo≈øt moderate of your coate, in pre≈øence of his Maje≈øty, [who≈øe mercifull di≈øpo≈øition, & aver≈øion to violent cour≈øes, is knowne] haue ≈øo much of this Dung, what can we gue≈ø≈øe of your hot headed Prophets among≈øt their furious blind Zealots?

And now, o ye Prei≈øts (Par≈øons) this commandment is for you. (I v≈øe the words of Malachy. 2.) If ye will not heare, & if ye will not lay to hart, to giue glory to my name, ≈øayth the Lord of Ho≈øts, I will even ≈øend a cur≈øe vpon you, & I will cur≈øe your Ble≈ø≈øings: yea I haue cur≈øed them already, becau≈øe you do not lay to hart. Behold I will reproue your ≈øeede [your whole Mini≈øtry] & ≈øpread dung vpon your faces, even the dung of your ≈øolemne Fea≈øts [5. noven] & it shall take you away with it. Which words are ≈øoe cleerly verifyed in our days, of your Gunpowder Fea≈øt in England, that they ≈øeeme not an Ob≈øcure Prophecy of a thing to come; but a Relation of a thing pa≈øt, or de≈øcription of one pre≈øent. How little you glorify God's name, on this day, I haue ≈øayd already. That God Hath cur≈øed the≈øe your Ble≈ø≈øings, & ≈øpread the dung of this ≈øolemnity vpon the face of the whole English Protestant Church, is evident: for from the yeare 1641. that fyery Zeale again≈øt Popery, which your ≈øelues had kindled, & entertained, fell on your owne Church, as Popish, & tooke it away with it, & Monarchy al≈øo: leaving ≈øcarce any hopes of re≈øtoring either. And againe with in the≈øe la≈øt fiue yeares how neere it brought both again to ≈øubver≈øion, & vtter ruin, you cannot but know. And how greate was the danger of this Fea≈øt Being turned into mourning, as Amos foretold c. 8.10. is evident, whence our vigilant Magi≈øtrates were moved to forbid Bone fires, tho≈øe ordinary ≈øignes of joy: as the be≈øt meanes to prevent ≈øome di≈ømall effects of that Malice, which you of the Mini≈øtry keepe ≈øtill vp at heygth, alth√¥ you haue found it fatal to both Church & State.

Yet I am not convinced, that Prohibiting bone fires is a remedy proportioned to the evil, that is feared, or rather felt, as long as you by your reproaches, & invectiues, are permitted to entertaine
that hatred of Popery: it is only to cut off a branch, & leaue the tree, to skin a wound, & leaue the Arrow head in it: not to quench; but to cover a fire, which when lea≈øt expected will breake out into new flames. For if you are permitted to ≈øound the Allarme, what wonder tho≈øe who deferre too much to your words should take it, & being fryghted out of their wits, by your repre≈øentation of their danger, they mi≈øtake a Troyan for a Grecian, & ≈øome blows levelled at Papi≈øts, fall on Papi≈øts in Ma≈øquerade? In fine your Gunpowder ≈øermons preach the People into gunpowder: & then a little sparke is enough to ≈øet them on fire, & blow all to pieces. And at who≈øe dore mu≈øt this lye, but yours, who di≈øpo≈øe all to it?

One ob≈øervation more, & I pa≈ø≈øe this point. Factious men, who make v≈øe of your labours to your de≈øtruction, are greate proficients in the Art of promoting mi≈øcheife. Forty yeares a goe it co≈øt them much labour, mony, bloud, & time, to get their armed Mirmidons about the Kings per≈øon: within the≈øe four yeares, few houres were enough to bring 20000. armed men. to Temple Barre, neere the King's Palace: & who knows but the next attempt will bring them to, or within his gates. Deus omen avertat, ≈øay I, as well as you. But humanely ≈øpeaking, that can ≈øcarce be avoyded, without God's opening your eyes to ≈øee the mi≈øcheife, you promote, or ≈øtirring vp publicke Authority to ≈øtop your mouths. Otherwi≈øe, You conceiue chaffe, you bring forth ≈øtubble, your ≈øpirit, as fire, will devour you. I≈øayas 33.11. Now to your ≈øermon.

In your 16. fir≈øt pages I ≈øee little to the purpo≈øe. The greate≈øt part is De communi Sanctorum, appliable to other things, mingled with ≈øome ≈ølips, through inadvertency: ≈øuch J take that to be, p. 13. S. Paul ≈øaw it with his owne eyes: when he ≈øays him≈øelf, 1. cor. 1.11. He heard it from tho≈øe of Chloe.
3. D. M. p. 17. This horrid con≈øpiracy, to which the Actors were prompted by ≈øome Doctrines of their Religion.

Rev. That it was a Horrid con≈øpiracy, J grant; but not, that the Doctrines of our Religion prompted the Actors vnto it. Let experience
decide the cau≈øe. What Kings more ab≈øolute in their Dominions, then Catholicks? In England when were our Kings more honoured, & readily obeyed, by their ≈øubjects, than when Papi≈øts? when more beloved by their freinds, and Allyes, when more feared by their Enemyes, than when Papi≈øts? Popery teachs to giue every one his due: to God, what is Gods, & to Cae≈øar, what is his: that is, it teaches to obey both Prelate & Prince, both ≈øpiritual & temporal Magi≈øtrate. Whereas your Reformation quite ca≈øt off obedience to the Prelate, & ≈øo weakened that to the Prince, that this broke too. And alth√¥ you haue endeavoured to piece it againe, yet the common voice ≈øays, that without a do≈øe of Popery, or Popish principles, it can never arriue to its former vigour. So different are the judgments of the world from your pretences! But what are the≈øe Doctrines?
D. M. p. 19, That of the Popes ≈øupremacy not of order, or precedency Only; but of Authority, & juri≈ødiction.

Rev. That ≈øupremacy had been acknowledged 1000. yeares, & yet Monarchy remained in its vigour: & ≈øo it continues in Spaine, & France, & Germany, without any bad effect to Monarchy. But you lay the faults of your Reformation at our dore. Then you cite ≈øome hard opinions out of Bellarmin, & Aug. Steucus, who being no Rules of our Faith, I pa≈ø≈øe by them.
D. M. p. 21. The Clergy was forbidden to marry that they myght haue no tye to their country: & exempted from ≈øecular juri≈ødiction, that it myght depend only on the Pope.

Rev. You ≈øpeake more dogmatically, than the Pope, for in doctrinal points, he giues a Rea≈øon, & you giue none. You may find other motiues for the≈øe two points, if you con≈øult our Divines, or Controverti≈øts.
D. M. p. 22. Oaths cannot bind them to their Allegiance Becau≈øe 1. they take them with Aequivocation. 2. The Pope can di≈øpen≈øe in them. 3. They keepe no faith with Hereticks.

Rev. Such ≈øtuffe myght pa≈ø≈øe in Oates's narratiue, or rayling I.
Philips, before the Rabble; but ≈øcarce in one of your degree before ≈øuch an Auditory. If Oaths to vs are ≈øuch Cobwebs, why do ≈øo many of vs loo≈øe their E≈øtates, their Libertys, & their Liues, rather than take ≈øome? Why doth the Parliament take the Paines to frame, & impo≈øe them? You contradict experience, & I feare, your owne Con≈øcience.
D. M. p. 23. Another horrid Doctrine, is the obligation of Prei≈øts, to conceale what they heare in Confe≈ø≈øion. And you mention Clement, & Ravaillac.

Rev. You myght with as much rea≈øon, haue mentioned Brutus & Pau≈øanias: for it doth not appeare that ether of the≈øe two ever di≈øcovered their de≈øigne in Confe≈ø≈øion. The ≈øecret of Confe≈ø≈øion may bring a Ruffian to di≈øcover his damnable intention to a Prei≈øt, by whome he may be diverted, or the mi≈øcheife prevented: & Divines teach how, without breaking the ≈øeale of Confe≈ø≈øion. But it giues no advantage to a Prei≈øt to communicate bad de≈øignes, becau≈øe the obligation of ≈øecrecy binds not the Penitent.

D. M. p. 24. It is not enough to ≈øay, the≈øe are not Doctrines of the Church of Rome; but only of ≈øome particular Doctors of it: becau≈øe they never were condemned by the repre≈øentatiue Body of that Church, &c.

Rev. A di≈øcour≈øe much below your ≈øelf, & your Auditory, yet you repeate it againe p. 30. What obligation is there, that if one do a thing contrary to his duty, all tho≈øe of his Communion mu≈øt by ≈øome publicke act declare again≈øt it. Doth a man ≈øu≈øpect his ≈øon, of taking a pur≈øe, if another doth ≈øo? Or his wife of being vnfaithfull to him, becau≈øe his neyghbour's wife is ≈øo? Or you & your breth, ren, to be in a readine≈ø≈øe to take vp Armes again≈øt the King, becau≈øe a Bishop did ≈øo? Becau≈øe that man's ≈øon, or wife, or the Bishops never declared their abhorrence, of tho≈øe ≈øeveral Crimes?

Moreover ≈øome of the Doctrines, you mention, are cen≈øured by our Church, in Santarelli, & Becanus. In France, & Rome it ≈øelf: which you knew, & therefore ≈øay They were not condemned by the repre≈øentatiue body of the Church, that is, a general Council. But if
you reade the la≈øt Chapter of S. Au≈øtins fourth book Contra duas Epi≈øtolas Pelagianorum, you will find that generall Councils are not always nece≈ø≈øary to condemne emergent errours, that many more haue beene condemned out of, than in Councils; that without an ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity [all other meanes fayling] the Church v≈øes not to haue recours to a general Council. Indeed were it not ≈øo, ≈øuch Councils mu≈øt ether be perpetual, & ≈øo the cheife Pa≈øtors would be always ab≈øent from their flocks, or be ≈øo frequent, that they would ≈øcarce ever re≈øide with it. Wherefore God hath appointed in the Church for ordinary & more frequent occa≈øions inferiour Tribunals, ≈øome of which haue declared already their di≈ølike of ≈øome of the≈øe Doctrines: others they leaue, as likely to wither of them≈øelues, Sicut foenum tectorum, as hay on the hou≈øe top: & ≈øome it may be are left, as not being legally knowne to tho≈øe Tribunalls. How ever ether there is, or is not, an obligation to condemne all bad Doctrines? If there is none, why do you blame our Church for omitting it? Jf there is one, how can you excu≈øe your owne Church, which never complyed with that Duty? In reality there is an obligation, which being a po≈øitiue precept, obliges in time & place; not alwais: & is ≈øo kept by vs; not at all by you.
D. M. p. 25. Bishop Andrews tells vs, that Paul IV. offred to confirme all that Q. Eli≈øabeth had done in Church affayres, vpon condition she would owne his ≈øupremacy.

Rev. This requires a better proofe, than the bare word of one intere≈ø≈øed man. How ever if it were ≈øo, the guilt of Schi≈øme ≈øticks clo≈øer to you: & you may ≈øee how much you were mi≈øtaken, when you told F. Darcy at Bru≈ø≈øelles, that one Side was re≈øolved before hand to relax nothing. But it is an ordinary cu≈øtome among≈øt you, to make vs hold contradictory things, as they ≈øerue your turne.
D. M. p. 26. The ea≈øterne ≈øchi≈øme was cau≈øed by the Pope's a≈ø≈øuming the title of vniver≈øal Bishop: & of being Head of the whole Church.

Rev. That cannot be: for the Pope never tooke the title of Vniver≈øal Bishop. And that other, Head of the Church, was acknowledged
by the 2. General Council: you pre≈øide over vs, as a Head over its members. Says that Council.
D. M. p. 27. & 28. Cates by ≈øayd this, & F. Garnet ≈øayd that, &c.
Rev. Iu≈øt the ≈øtile of Oates's narratiue, & myght ≈øerue as a Modele of it.
D. M. p. 30. They ≈øuffer Garnet, & Oldcorne to be put into the Catalogue of Martyrs, by the Je≈øuits.

Rev. If they do ≈øo, it is becau≈øe they judge them Innocent of the Trea≈øon, for which they ≈øuffred; not that they like the Trea≈øon it ≈øelf. Thus ≈øeveral haue written in defence of ≈øome Per≈øons lately accu≈øed of Trea≈øon, beleiving them to be innocent of it, who hate Trea≈øon more hartily, than ether Oates, or Shaftesbury, the grand promoters of that Accu≈øation.
D. M. p. 31. Beware of fal≈øe Prophets, who come to you in sheepe's cloathing; but are inwardly wolues, nay ravening wolues.

Rev. The ≈øame I ≈øay: yet ≈øtill I wish it were not in the Power of every malicious man, to call Wolf & then all the dogs in the country shall be ≈øet on a Sheepe, & worry it. Which hath beene lately done on this ≈øide the line, to the a≈øtonishment of the world, & no little di≈øcredit of our Nation.
D. M. p. 32. It is not their per≈øecution, but our owne pre≈øervation that we contend for.

Rev. The law of nature obliges you to ≈øeeke Self pre≈øervation: but Prudence mu≈øt guide you in the choice of proper meanes to find it. And Experience is the be≈øt rule of Prudence: & this demon≈øtrates, that Per≈øecution of Papi≈øts, is the way to Ruin; not to Pre≈øerue your ≈øelues. For about 70. yeares, through the mercy of our Kings we haue had but two Per≈øecutions of Papi≈øts, & both opened a dore to Factious. Rebells, who the fir≈øt time ruined both Church, & State: & the ≈øecond time brought both to the brink of a precipice, & downe both had gon, had there not been put a ≈øtop to the preceedings again≈øt Papi≈øts. So the Per≈øecution of Papists is ≈øuch a remedy to your fainting Church, as cutting his throate is to a man in an Ague.

p.hi: Dic mihi, num furor e≈øt, ne moriare mori?

div.p: Will any man in his wits, pre≈øcribe ≈øuch phy≈øicke?

D. M. p. 34. I will add for ju≈øtifying the laws made against Papi≈øts, that if they ≈øeeme to haue a watchfull eye, & hold a ≈øtricter hand over them in jealous times, they mu≈øt thank them≈øelues, who refu≈øe to take, & the Pope, who forbids them to take the Oaths.

Rev. I wish you had explicated, what you meane by Iealous times? Whither ≈øuch as are occa≈øioned by ≈øome Actions, or de≈øignes of Papi≈øts, again≈øt your Church, or State? Or without any cau≈øe, be≈øides the phancy of ≈øome melancholy Par≈øon, or the Calumnyes of ≈øome ≈øuch Flagitious wretches, as of late appeared on the English stage? If your jealou≈øyes are are of the fir≈øt ≈øort, no body will blame your ≈øeverity, vpon the guilty Per≈øons. If they haue no other ground but the dreames of a fancifull Par≈øon, or the word, & Oath, of an Oates, or a Bedlow, who would ≈øtarue or be hanged, if by ≈øuch a tricke they did not get a meales meate, and their necke out of a halter, by a Pardon: I leaue you to judge, whither this doth ju≈øtify your ≈øtrict hand; & not rather aggravate it. A wi≈øe man ≈øayd: England is in a ≈øtrange condition! For if any man in the Parliament do but cry, Popery, they will act, & decree, as if they were be≈øides them≈øelues. Is this a laudable di≈øpo≈øition of the Body Politick? Would our taking the Oaths cure this di≈øtemper, when you your ≈øelf in this very ≈øermon tell the world, that no Oaths can bind vs? Me thinks an vnblemisht loyalty both acting, & ≈øuffring, as is our duty to the Royal Authority in ≈øuch variety of hard times, as we haue ≈øeene, myght be a better a≈ø≈øurance, than ≈øuch Cobwebs, as you de≈øcribe them.
D. M. p. 38. The Church of Rome v≈øes greater ≈øeverity in Spaine, & Jtaly, &c.

Rev. We are very thankfull to his Maje≈øty for The grace he shews vs, either in quite ≈øu≈øpending, or abating the rigour of the law: & we-acknowledge it as an act of Mercy. yet giue me leaue to tell you, that our ca≈øe in England, is far different from that of Prote≈øtants either in Spaine, or Italy: we brought Chri≈øtianity to the English Nation: your Bishops, & Prei≈øts, your Hierarchy & Orders, if you haue
any, you haue them from vs. Your Churchs we built, & founded, your Celledges & Vniver≈øityes are our Donations: Your Canon, & Civil law, your Sacred, & prophane learning are the product of our ≈øtudyes. The very Rites, & ceremonyes, which you v≈øe, you borrowed from vs. Which of all the≈øe things did Prote≈øtants bring, & ≈øettle in Italie, or Spaine? If none; then certainly the ca≈øe of Catholicks in England, is not the ≈øame, with that of Protestants, in Catholick countryes.
D. M. p. 38. Let me intreate you all to joine with me in this short prayer.

Rev. We willingly giue God thanks for pre≈øerving the Nation from ruin: & pray him to continu his protection to it: & that He will giue our Dread ≈øoveraigne along life, a peaceable reigne, a wi≈øe Council, faithfull Mini≈øters, stout ≈øouldiers, & an obedient, contented, & vnited people, without tho≈øe groundle≈ø≈øe animo≈øitys, which you of the Mini≈øtry foment. Amen.

div.head:
SECTION XIX. A Revi≈øion of the Letter to her R. H.
1. The publishing of this Letter vnexpected.
2. What kind of Directors are the Mini≈øters?
3. The report of the change of her R. H.
4. Motiues alleadged to retaine her in the Prote≈øtant Religion.
5. Spiritual ≈øtate of the Prote≈øtant Church.
div.p:
1. I Was very much ≈øurprized, to ≈øee this letter made publick, much more, that is was by your order, by rea≈øon of the character you bore, of Confe≈ø≈øor to her R. H. For a far different rea≈øon, there ought to be as greate a freedome of communication betwixt Confe≈ø≈øor, & Penitent, in matters of Con≈øcience, as to the ≈øoul, as
betwixt Man, & Wife, as to the Body. Which liberty is much checeed, with the thought, that ≈øuch things may ≈øome day become publicke. The people of Athens would not let Philip of Macedon's letters to his wife Olimpias be opened, th√¥ he were an Enemy, as thinking the conver≈øe betwixt ≈øuch per≈øons, ≈øacred. With more rea≈øon ought tho≈øe betwixt Confe≈ø≈øor, & Penitent, be looked on as ≈øuch. But it ≈øeemes in the Protestant Church nether ≈øecret is regarded: for that betwixt Man & Wife was broken by order of Parliament, for the printing the letters of king Charles I. to the Queene, & you, a father of the Prote≈øtant Church publish tho≈øe betwixt your Penitent, & you. And J heare that ≈øome per≈øons of your Communion haue found, that they had not made their Confe≈ø≈øions them≈øelues to Mute fishes. Witne≈ø≈øe Capt. Hinde.

Catholickes haue indeed printed a letter of a Prei≈øt to my Lord of Stafford, & ≈øomething written as is beleived by her R. H. but nether of the≈øe comes home to the point of this letter. For what was written by her R. H. was probably de≈øigned to be ≈øeene, at lea≈øt it was not written to her Confe≈ø≈øor: nor was that letter to my Lord of Stafford, by his Confe≈ø≈øor, it myght, & probably did come from one, who never ≈øaw him, nor knew of him, but onely that he was preparing for Death.

Another rea≈øon, why I was ≈øurprized at the ≈øyght of this letter, is that it doth in a manner confirme the Report of her being a papist. Now this lady being by alliance entred into the Royal Family, & making a very eminent figure in it, I thought shee should haue beene partaker of that priviledge, that none should publish their being Papi≈øts: for if this be Trea≈øon by law, when ≈øayd of the head of that Family, it ought to be held a hainous offence, when ≈øpoken of others. Be≈øides this, we learne in Tobie, 12.11. That it is Good to reveale the ≈øecrets of God; & to conceale tho≈øe of the King. So that whereas Divines are permitted to dine as deepe as they can into Divine my≈øterys, as to tho≈øe of the King they are to remember, that Qui ≈øcrutator e≈øt Maje≈øtatis, opprimetur a glori√¢, He that pryes into
Maje≈øty shall be oppre≈øt with glory Prou. 25.27. Death to the foole hardy.

2. The booke called Anti Haman p. 309. hath the≈øe words: There ≈øeemes to be as much difference, betwixt the ≈øpiritual food, which ≈øouls receiue in the Catholick Church, & that of Prote≈øtants, as there is betwixt the nourriture a child receives ≈øucking a brea≈øt, ≈øtretched with milke, & that he gets, by ≈øucking a moi≈øtned finger. We haue an occa≈øion here to ≈øee whither this judgment be well grounded.

Two things are remarkable in the in≈øtructions, which Mini≈øters giue to the ≈øouls vnder their direction, as appeares by their ≈øermons, & ≈øpiritual bookes. 1. A horrour, & hatred of Popery. 2. A ≈ølyght touch of ≈øome hole≈øome Catholick Truths, yet ≈øo handled, as not to moue con≈øiderably the ≈øoul, for feare it moue them too far. For example, they ≈øpeaking of ≈øome former ≈øins, the ≈øorrow for them, the purpo≈øe of amendment: the preventing God's judgments, by judging our ≈øelves, & appea≈øing his wrath by Penitencial workes, they do it well; yet knowing that tho≈øe points are meere Popery, to prevent their pa≈ø≈øing over to it they added an Antidote, which de≈øtroyes all they had ≈øayd. One in≈øtance shall ≈øuffice. Dr Hewit, Repentance, & Conver≈øion p. 51. hath the≈øe words: we mu≈øt confe≈øse to men, & that both privately, & publickly, according to the quality of the ≈øin, (This is catholick Doctrine: now he corrects it) For though we condemne Auricular Confe≈ø≈øion, as a trick of ≈øtate Policy; yet we allow, & exhort all Chri≈øtians to a tru, voluntary, & ≈øincere Confe≈ø≈øion of their ≈øins to the Bishop, & ≈øuperintendents of the Church. Thus he. Now what is Private Confe≈ø≈øion, but Auricular Confe≈ø≈øion? Yet to the one he exhorts; the other he condemnes: or rather he approues, & condemnes the ≈øame thing vnder different names. And what is this, but to build with one hand, & pull downe with the other? to plant, & roote vp, the ≈øame thing? To teach in Churchs, as tru Prote≈øtant evidences depo≈øe in Courts plaine Downe ryght contradictions?

Now what can a ≈øoul do, hearing this, if she be truly de≈øirous of ≈øalvation? Practice tho≈øe Truths? They bring her to Popery? Then they cannot ≈øeriou≈øly practice what you teach. This inward
combate ≈øeldome cea≈øes, till they leaue the Prote≈øtant Communion: for either they become immediatly Papi≈øts, if the loue of vertu overcomes: or Presbiterians, if the hatred of Papi≈øts prevailes, by the helpe of a Moro≈øe nature. Thus the ≈øure≈øt tyes to Prote≈øtaney ≈øeeme to be, 1. a carele≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe of what is to come in the next world, 2. a Pre≈øumption of God's goodne≈ø≈øe, & 3. Temporal motiues of all ≈øizes. All which are in≈øignificant to a ≈øoul, that prefers her eternal concerne, before her temporal, & re≈øolues to advance in vertu an Earth, that shee may be more gratefull to her cele≈øtial ≈øpou≈øe in Heaven.

3. For this rea≈øon the report of the change in Religion, of her R. H. ea≈øily found credit with me. Of which report, you ≈øpeake p. 4. & 5. God had giuen her a ≈øerious de≈øire to ≈øerue him, as he would be ≈øerved. I heard she was earne≈øt in pur≈øuing what she thought was for his glory, attentiue in her Devotions, & exact in performing what ≈øeemed to be the will of God, & for the good of her ≈øoul: & that though her Fortune was exceeding greate, yet she would rather forgoe it all, then hazard her ≈øoul: that Jewell being too precious, to be compen≈øated with any thing. God had Giuen her an extraordinary good vnder≈øtanding, ≈øay you p. 14. with which she could ea≈øily di≈øcerne betwixt what was Tru, & what onely Seemed to be ≈øo. Whence without any helpe of Bookes, or in≈øtructions of men, by only Hearing the di≈øcour≈øe of Religion (which is the mo≈øt common in England, & will be ≈øo, till men talke them≈øelues either out of all Religion, or into a good one, either into Athei≈øme, or Popery) she myght ea≈øily di≈øcover, that the devil was not ≈øo vgly, as he was painted: that ≈øomethings were charged on vs, which we did not hold: & that what we really taught, was not Blame worthy: ≈øoe on both ≈øides we were jnnocent. And probably she myght declare ≈øo much, being vnwilling to heare vs wronged. Which gaue you occa≈øion to ≈øay, p. 4. that shee Declared in favour of Papi≈øts, & grounded that Report, of her being one.

Then you ≈øpend ≈øeveral pages in proving how fatal a like Report
had beene to her Father-in-law, K. Charles I. & what prejudice it had like to haue done to Charles II. altho both were jnnocent of that Crime, & aver≈øe to the Religion. Which confirmes what I ≈øayd, how dangerous it is to entertaine that animo≈øity again≈øt Popery, which enables knaues to compa≈ø≈øe the ruin of hone≈øt men, even the King him≈øelf, with only traducing him, or them, as Papi≈øts, how jnnocent ≈øoever they be, & aver≈øe to that Religion.
D. M. p. 12. It is Impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øilence this Report (of your being a Papi≈øt) vnle≈ø≈øe you your ≈øelf appeare in it, & vpon all occa≈øions declare your dete≈øtation of it. &c.

Rev. How in≈øignificant this remedy would haue proved, appeares by its ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in the late King's time: Who≈øe declarations of that nature, even at the Communion, could not ≈øilence his Enemyes, nor check a like report.
D. M. p. 15. None shall ever be able to proue, that either we omit any thing nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation: or teach any thing de≈øtructiue to it.

Rev. Your Schi≈øme is de≈øtructiue to Salvation. It is vndeniable that Schi≈ømaticks remaming ≈øuch cannot be≈øaved; They shall not haue God for their father, who haue not the Church for their mother. S. Cyprian. And you are in a Schi≈øme. I myght alleadge ≈øeveral other things de≈øtructiue to Salvation: but this one is enough.
D. M. p. 17. & 18. The Papi≈øts ≈øay there is no ≈øalvation, out of their Church. The Donati≈øts ≈øayd ≈øo too. And was it not for that, ≈øaying ≈øo, that they were pronounced Hereticks?

Revi≈øor: Here are three gro≈ø≈øe mi≈øtakes, of which I haue ≈øpoken ≈øec. 4. The 1. that the donati≈øts ≈øayd there was no ≈øalvation out of their Church. Their grande errour was, that the Church was lo≈øt by communicating with a ≈øinner. All their other errours were but ≈øequels of this: viz that there was no Church, but theirs, the re≈øt of the Chri≈øtians communicating with Cecilianus, who had delivered vp the holy bookes. 2. That there was no valid Bapti≈øme but in their Communion. 3. That the ≈øon, was le≈ø≈øer than the father, & the Holy gho≈øt, than the ≈øon. See S. Au≈øtin l. de Hereticis ad
Quod vult Deum ¬ß. 69. & Epi. Baronij ad annu Dom. 321. n. 4. For the≈øe errours the donati≈øts were tru Herticks. But for ≈øaying, that Here≈øy de≈øtroys ≈øalvation, they could not be Hereticks, vnle≈ø≈øe you will make S. Athana≈øius one, who ≈øays in his creede: Quam, fidem, ni≈øi qui≈øque integram inviolatamque ≈øervaverit, ab≈øque dubio in aeternum peribit. No hopes of ≈øalvation, where any point of Faith is denyed.
The 2. That they were pronounced Hereticks for ≈øaying ≈øo. They were pronounced Hereticks for ≈øaying other things: as J haue shewne.

The 3. that they were held for Hereticks. The Catholick Church held them at fir≈øt for Sci≈ømaticks, & ≈øuch they were; but not for Hereticks. The Catholicks exacted nothing of them, but that they should joine Communion with them: they offred to that intent, that in tho≈øe cittyes, which had two Bishops, one of each Communion, the ≈øurviver, which ≈øoever it was, should governe alone the Dioce≈øe, that by that meanes the Schi≈øme myght be extinguisht. A condition never offred to any Heretick, or Hereticks what ≈øoever. At la≈øt indeed they turned tru Hereticks, as I ≈øayd, on another ≈øcore.
D. M. p. 19. For you to conclude in favour of Popery, without hearing Prote≈øtants, is that which cannot be done either in Equity, or Con≈øcience.

Rev. She did not conclude for one ≈øide, without hearing the other, She had heard Prote≈øtants from her jnfancy, & had weyghed maturely what they could ≈øay for them≈øelues, or again≈øt Popery. It is wonderfull, that a short Conference with ≈øome Papi≈øt, [it could be no more, if there were ≈øo much] should be of force ≈øufficient to roote vp all tho≈øe prejudices again≈øt God's Church, which you ≈øo carefull in≈øtill to tho≈øe vnder your conduct, alth√¥ they had bin confirmed by long practice, & reiterated Acts contrary to the Catholick Faith: & all the≈øe backed with almo≈øt the greate≈øt temporal intere≈øt in the world: for on the one ≈øide, she ≈øaw honour, Riches, & the probable expectation of our Imperial crowne; on the other, Reproaches, Calumnyes, di≈øgrace, & probably a tragical End, for
≈øuch had been the fate of her Father-in-law indeed; & what mi≈øery, or vnju≈øtice is ≈øo evident, ≈øo greate, as a Papi≈øt may not feare from a Tru Prote≈øtant? But Magna veritas, & praevalet: Truth ≈øeconded by God's interiour grace, & a≈ø≈øi≈øted by her generous re≈øolution, never to admit the whole world into con≈øideration, when her ≈øoul was concerned, overcame all tho≈øe difficultyes. With this Truly Heroical re≈øolution you acquaint vs. For you ≈øay to her.

D. M. p. 21. You your ≈øelfe haue told me more then once, (even ≈øince this fal≈øe report hath beene ray≈øed of you) that you would not do any thing, whereby you myght ≈øeeme to be of a Church, or Religion, which you are not of indeed; no not for any wordly con≈øideration what≈øoever. And p. 22. you are wont to ≈øay, that no wordly either Advantage, or Prejudice, is to be con≈øidered, when the gaining of the One, or the avoyding of the Other, comes into competition with the hazarding, or ≈øecuring of our ≈øpiritual, & everlasting jntere≈øt of our ≈øouls: & con≈øequently, that if you were convinced there were no Salvation to be had, but in the Church of Rome, no con≈øideration either of Lo≈ø≈øe, or of Danger here in this world, you myght incur by it, should keepe you from it.
Rev. Out of the≈øe truly Chri≈øtian Re≈øolutions, often declared to you, I gather many material points, either vnknowne before, or not ≈øufficiently knowne.
1. That her R. H. was really enclined to be a Catholick. So that Report was grounded.
2. That you knew this inclination.

3. That you endeavoured to divert her from it, alleadging cheifly temporal intere≈øt, to divert her from becoming a Papi≈øt. This J gather out of tho≈øe declarations, which she ≈øo often made: & out of this very letter, which containes little, if any thing at all el≈øe.

4. That either you, which I do not beleiue, or ≈øome other Prote≈øtant, advi≈øed her to di≈ø≈øemble in matter of Religion, & profe≈ø≈øe her ≈øelf a Prote≈øtant, th√¥ she were not ≈øo. What other occa≈øion could she haue to make that declaration, that She would not do any thing to ≈øeeme to be of a Church of which she was not, for all the world?

La≈øtly, that she was too generous to be fryghted with ≈øuch Bug beares. When her ≈øoul lay at ≈øtake: knowing full well, it Would availe her nothing to gaine the whole world, if she lo≈øt that. Mar. 8.36.

5. Thus this letter confirmes what was ≈øayd, but not commonly beleived, of the Religion in which her R. H. dyed, that she truly was a Catholick, or as you call vs, a Papi≈øt: for you owne her inclination that way, & you had little to alleadge to divert her from it, but temporal intere≈øt: which was as little able to retaine her, as a cobweb to hold a Lion: ≈øo it is impo≈ø≈øible to mi≈ø≈øe in the conjecture of the event.

But what judgment will the world make of your Church, out of this letter? The concerne you writ for, was as greate almo≈øt as could occurre, the retaining within your Communion a per≈øon, as con≈øiderable almo≈øt, as any what≈øoever, a per≈øon worthily e≈øteemed as greate for her qualifications of mind, as to vertu, & vnder≈øtanding, as for her dignity in the Kingdome: a per≈øon, who was a greate ornament to your Church, nay a Piller of it. So no doubt but all indu≈øtry was v≈øed to prevent her leaving you: & that what≈øoever your Art, your wit, & learning could doe, was employed to that intent, & we may gue≈ø≈øe, that as the cau≈øe was common, ≈øo the concurrence was: & therefore we may conjecture, that all the nerues of the Protestant Church joined to giue this Blow. Yet how weake, how incon≈øiderable is it!

And is then your Glorious Apo≈øtolical reformed Church come to this? Haue you no motiues, to commend her Communion, & retaine pious ≈øouls in it, but Temporal? will the≈øe weygh downe in the ≈øcales of rea≈øon all con≈øiderations of Eternity? And if they should be judged weyght, by men, will God judge ≈øo too? At the greate day, will it be a ≈øufficient excu≈øe for Schi≈øme, & Here≈øy, to ≈øay: I was affrayd of loo≈øing my e≈øtate, of hindring my fortune, of offending my freinds, of giving advantage to my Enemys? Will not Christ an≈øwer. Seing You haue di≈øowned me, & my Church, before men, I will di≈øowne you before my father?

I will not deny, but you haue given ≈øatisfaction, as to what concernes your ≈øelf, that you are a Prote≈øtant. Yet J mu≈øt profe≈ø≈øe, you giue little ≈øatisfaction, as to your Church. Nay I do declare, that I would never de≈øire other, nor better grounds to vindicate the Truth of Catholick Religion, & the nece≈ø≈øity of living in the Communion of the Catholick Church, than what this letter affords. For by it, we may gather the condition of the Prote≈øtant Church to be like that of Laodicea, Apoc. 3.17. Wretched, & mi≈øerable, & poore, & blind, & naked. I hartily wish you & tho≈øe of your ranke, were truly ≈øen≈øible of this Truth, & that you made a ryght v≈øe of it, by ≈øeeking ways to returne to the Communion of the Catholick Roman Church: & ≈øo put an end to this horrid Schi≈øme. Though the difficultyes to be overcome were greate, yet greate difficultyes ought not to fryght vs from ≈øo greate, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary a good, as that of the Peace of the Church. But in reality they are le≈ø≈øe, then apprehended, which you mu≈øt ≈øay, if you beleiue, what you report after Bishop Andrews, that the Pope was willing to confirme all, that Q. Elizabeth had done in matter of Religion, provided she would acknowledge his Supremacy. This is then the grand, nay the only ob≈øtacle. Now all, who haue been conver≈øant in Catholick countryes, & ≈øee their cu≈øtomes, even where that Supremacy is acknowledged, ≈øee cleerly, that this is no ≈øuch formidable thing, as to excu≈øe, & ju≈øtify a ≈øeparation: & by con≈øequence can be no ju≈øt hindrance of Peace. which the God of Peace grant vs: & giue all Schi≈ømaticks a tru de≈øire of. Amen.

div.head: SECTION XX. A Revi≈øion of his Letter to a Prei≈øt.
div.p: WHo this Regular Prei≈øt is, you do not tell vs; yet what you ≈øay, of him, & he of him≈øelf, de≈øcribe him by infallible notes. You endeavour to proue in this letter to him, three things.

list.item: 1. That being ≈øo perswaded, as he was, he was bound in Con≈øcience to leaue the Communion of the Roman Church.
2. That he was bound to joine Communion, with the Prote≈øtant Church of England.
3. That he was bound to do it out of hand.

div.p: Which Propo≈øitions are built one vpon another, the third on the ≈øecond, & this on the fir≈øt. Which being Conditional; not Ab≈øolute: ≈øuppo≈øing his Pre≈øent perswa≈øion, we mu≈øt ≈øee what that is: & according to this Meridian we mu≈øt calculate his Duty.

What this poore man's Perswa≈øion is, (if he haue any ≈øetled) is hard to judge of. He hath vowed Obedience to his Regular Superiour; & will not keepe it. He hath vowed Poverty, & breakes that vow. He profe≈ø≈øe the Catholick Faith, & beleiues it full of Errors, nay Here≈øyes. He ≈øays, he will remaine in the Communion of the Roman Catholick Church, & yet beleiues her to be Heretick, & Schi≈ømatick. He hath beene ordred backe to his Convent; & he refu≈øes to returne: he hath been Canonically admonisht of his extravagances, & he ≈ølights it: he hath been Excommunicated, & he Laughs at it. In fine, in him Hereticks find a con≈øtant freind, Schi≈ømaticks a ≈øure Advocate, Apo≈øtates, a certaine Patrone, & Catholicks an implacable Enemy; & yet he pretends he is nether Heretick, nor Schi≈ømatick, nor Apo≈øtata; but a Catholick, & member of the Roman Church,

Who can ≈øquare the≈øe circles, & reconcile the≈øe Contradictions, betwixt his Declarations & Actions, that ≈øo a judgment may be framed of his Tru Per≈øua≈øion? Whither shall we giue credit to, his declarations? Or his Actions? Tho≈øe ≈øpeake his being a Catholick, & he is nothing le≈ø≈øe. The≈øe declare his hatred to Catholicks, & their Religion, which yet he profe≈ø≈øeth. So we mu≈øt conclude him a Chimera, one compo≈øed of contradictions, & his Religion is made vp of parts mutually de≈øtroying one another. Or el≈øe, that he hath no Religion: for as a Chimera cannot haue a being In rerum natur√¢: ≈øo there can nether be an Entity compo≈øed of Contradictions, nor a Religion,
for the ≈øame rea≈øon. At lea≈øt at the greate Audit, he can never fayle to heare Di≈øcede a me, &c. Begon from me: & whither ≈øo ever Religion he be of, his owne words will condemne him: Ex ore tuo te judico, ≈øerve nequam.

What can hence be gathered, but that his Perswa≈øion being ≈øo vncertain, & his Religion ≈øo dubious, or certainly none at all, nothing can be thence gathered, as to the Communion, which he should enter into. If you think him well di≈øpo≈øed for your Church, you di≈øcover what kind of men it is compo≈øed of. Ours, that is the Catholick Church, doth not de≈øire ≈øuch, nor tolerate them, further than there is hopes of their amendment: & little, or none at all being left of this man, she hath ca≈øt him out by Excommunication: As I learne from your owne letter. So by what I ≈øee, I conclude that, You haue ≈øpoyled a Catholick, & not made a Prote≈øtant.

Yet to moue him to come quite over, you very learnedly di≈øtinguish three ages of the Church. The fir≈øt, while≈øt she continued in that Faith, which was once delivered to Saints. p. 31. The ≈øecond [p. 32.] from the time, the Pope tooke vpon him the title of vniver≈øal Bishop. Yet you are not re≈øolved what time to allow to this Second age, whither one thou≈øand, or eleven, or twelue hundred yeares. The third, (p. 42.) from the two Councils, of Lateran vnder LEO X. & Trent. jmplying, that all were bound to communicate with the Church of Rome in its fir≈øt age, myght communicate with it, in the ≈øecond; & mu≈øt not in the third. Jn the fir≈øt, Communion with it was a nece≈ø≈øary duty: in the ≈øecond, it was lawfull, but not nece≈ø≈øary: in the third vnlawfull, & a ≈øin. And the≈øe dreames take vp aboue 30. pages.

Rev. All this is a dreame: for the ≈øecond age, which you ≈øpeake of, is yet to come: the Pope never having taken the title of Vniver≈øal Bishop. Be≈øides this, Chri≈øt promi≈øt his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the Church not for any determinate time; but for all times: & a≈ø≈øured her of his pre≈øence, till the end of the world: now when you shall proue, that Chri≈øt hath broken, or can, or will, breake his word, we will
think your ≈øecond age po≈ø≈øible; not till then: ≈øo the fir≈øt age, in which all are obliged to joine in Communion with the Church of Rome, is not expired, nor will, nor can ever expire.

D. M. p. 62. Having quitted the Communion of the Roman Church, he is bound to joine with that of England, in Con≈øcience, it being the mo≈øt perfectly reformed Church in the world: & in Prudence, in order to the protection of his Per≈øon & provi≈øion for his future ≈øub≈øistance.

Rev. You boa≈øt much of the perfection of your Reformation: yet were never able to get it approved by any one externe Church, of what denomination ≈øoever: & how many, or rather how few do vniver≈øally approue it in England, appeares by the number of your Sectaryes, & Schi≈ømaticks. At what tribunal haue you not beene condemned, whereever you appeared? The Pope hath anathematized your Reformation: ≈øo hath the General Council of Trent, that Church repre≈øentatiue. This Amphibium, this your Anonimous Prei≈øt, ≈øays you appealed to the Church diffu≈øiue: which he gathers by the Apologyes you publisht for all men to ≈øee. But you haue had as ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe here, as at Trent, or Rome: having never been able to find any one Kingdome, or Province, or Citty, or any con≈øiderable number of particular men, who in all things approue your Reformation. So that you are in this inferiour to the Lutherans, to Calvini≈øts, to Anabapti≈øts, to Adamists, nay to Independents, & Quakers, &c. Who all haue in ≈øeveral countryes ≈øome of their Per≈øwa≈øion; but of yours none out of England: & how many even there, owne their vocation to your Reformation more to the Royal Authority, than to the force of the Truth, you teach, or the Beauty of your Church, which you commend?

D. M. p. 63. Prudence obliges him to the ≈øame: for He can hardly be ≈øafe any where beyond ≈øeas: & by joining with vs, he will: as al≈øo find provi≈øion for his ≈øub≈øi≈øtence: which you ≈øay you will vndertake shall not be wanting.

Rev. You ≈øow the fox's skin to that of a Lyon, & Spiritual motiues falling short, you piece them out with Temporal. When we call
to mind that within the≈øe fifty yeares your whole Church was turned out of God's Ble≈ø≈øing into the warme ≈øun, & that within the≈øe fiue yeares she was very neere the ≈øame fate, we may conclude, that there is not much greater a≈ø≈øurance of your Temporal, than of your Spiritual promi≈øes. Here I ob≈øerue two things:

The fir≈øt: that Temporal motiues are never omitted, when there is any hopes of gaining a Pro≈øelit. Indeed they are your be≈øt Card, as appeares by your v≈øing it ≈øo frequently: & by v≈øing it, you shew what weyght it hath with you.

The ≈øecond: that in this you differ very much from Papi≈øts, who propo≈øe hopes of eternal life, indeed; but as for this, they promi≈øe nothing but what Chri≈øt promi≈øt his Di≈øciples: 30.16.32. In mundo pre≈ø≈øuram habebitis: you shall be hated, calumniated, per≈øecuted, impri≈øoned, Opprest, hanged, In this world: But better all this, than to loo≈øe your ≈øoul, by Schi≈øme, & Here≈øy.
D. M. p. 64. It remaines therefore, that being obliged to quit the Communion of the Church of Rome, & joine with ours, of England, you are obliged to do this ≈øpeedily, &c.

Rev. All this falls to the ground: for there nether is, nor can be an obligation to quit the Church of Rome; there being an obligation to conforme to her, to ≈øubmit to her devi≈øions in matter of Divine Truths, & to renounce all errours, contrary to the tru Doctrine of Faith, which she teachs, & will teach to the end of the world.
